reviews.review_title: Well acted scenes do not pull together
reviews.content: Noah Baumbach is one of those filmmakers that is highly regarded in the "Art House" community for his semi-autobiographical humanistic films. These are domestic dramas heavy on dialogue - the type of film that "A-List" Actors swarm to perform in for the acting challenges it brings. His latest, MARRIAGE STORY, is no exception as it follows the dissolution of a marriage and the struggles of the 2 main players involved. The husband and wife are written realistically (according to Baumbach) with moments of pathos and moments of repulsion thrown in at equal measure.So, naturally, Baumbach (THE SQUID AND THE WHALE) was able to draw 2 of the better performers working in film today to play the leads - Scarlett Johannson and Adam Driver - and they deliver the goods (along with Laura Dern) - all 3 were deserved Oscar nominees - and the performances of ALL of the actors on screen are worth watching.But...that's about all this film has going for it. For I found the first hour and a half of this film tedious with (at times) preposterous dialogue that looked good on paper - and was enthusiastically performed - but wrang (at least to me) as unrealistic. Consequently, this film is filled with well acted scenes that I kept saying to myself - "that was a well acted scene and that was an interesting choice that that actor made in that scene", but I found that these disparate scenes in this part of the film did not hold together as a movie. It seemed to me a series of acting class scenes and not a film.And, for that, I blame Writer/Director Baumbach. This film, purportedly, parallels his divorce from actress Jennifer Jason Leigh (HATEFUL 8) and it shows. It's a little too "on the nose" and "inside baseball" for my tastes. The dialogue, at times, was "too cute" and the pacing was deliberate - which is a nice way of saying "slow".What saves this film is the performances. Johannson dominates the first part of this film and she brings her "A" game, bringing a strength and awakening purpose to her character that will have you rooting for her - at the beginning. The first half of the film (for the most part) is Johannson's film and is what gives her her Oscar nomination (she won't win), but she deserves the nomination.Laura Dern is also Oscar nominated for her role as Johannson's Divorce Attorney. Bright, funny, articulate and a shark in the courtroom and boardroom, Dern's character was fascinating to watch onscreen. While I thought this performance was "fine" and I was "okay" with it getting an Oscar nomination, I kept waiting for the "Oscar scene" for this supporting character - and about 2/3 of the way into the film this character had that moment - and Dern killed it. I would now say Dern is the deserved frontrunner for Best Supporting Actress (ironically, over Johansson who is ALSO nominated for Supporting Actress for JoJo Rabbit).This scene propels the last 1/3 of this film into interesting territory - a place that this film had not gone to thus far. I was sucked into this last part and I think it is in no small reason due to the fact that this part of the film is driven (no pun intended) by Adam Driver's character. I've always found Driver to be a fascinating actor and while his character was not front and center much in the first part of the film, he commands center stage in the last part and I could not take my eyes off of his powerful performance. In a strong year of Best Acting performances, he shines and I would be happily surprised and satisfied if he won the Best Actor Oscar.Alan Alda, as usual, brings an interesting character to the screen as does Julie Hagerty (remember her from AIRPLANE?) as Scarlett's mother. The surprise to me was the strong play of Ray Liotta as one of Driver's lawyers - it is his best work in quite some time and shows he does have some acting chops. Finally, good ol' Wallace Shawn (the "inconceivable" Count Visini in PRINCESS BRIDE) was fun - and annoying - in his scenes.So...if you want to see some good acting in scenes that I am sure will end up as good scenes in an acting class performed very strongly, then check out MARRIAGE STORY. Just make sure you are well rested. A fast-paced romp it is not.Letter Grade: B (for the strong performances)7 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

reviews.review_title: Marriage is the grave of love.
reviews.content: The divorce tore apart a man's self-made world of happiness, and everything had to revolve around him in the past. The two actors performed the complex emotion of love and hate.

Good acting, poorly written, the script puts you to sleep. Another movie with good actors and terrible writers.
Adam Driver is incredible in this raw and honest look at the demise of a committed relationship. Multi-faceted characters and believable performances.

Charlie Barber (Adam Driver) and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson looks like they have reached the end of the line in the marriage department. More a question of growing apart than exerting cruelty upon one another she moves to LA to do a series while Charlie a theatre director remains in NY. What remains important is access to their son and the semi-amicable break-up gets ugly when it gets litigious.Marriage Story is a high gloss soap opera in the tradition of Kramer versus Kramer featuring fine performances from Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansen as the marital combatants. The split is not due to unbridled hatred for each other but lack of communication in which there is more frustration than rage. Writer director Noah Bombach's real villains in the piece are the down and dirty lawyers (played with relish by Laura Dern and Ray Liotta) and the divorce laws that can bankrupt both financially and morally a family.Driver and Johansen display an excellent discordant chemistry with each other amid sterile settings that Baumbach applies some subtle incidentals to but the argumentation eventually grows repetitive with some moments contrived, others rushed and sloppy such as the one in which Charlie is being served. Piling on the suds Randy Newman contributes a score of heart tugging strings and woodwinds that give the impression you are watching a Hallmark Channel film with four letter words. Outside of the lead performances an overlong, banal coast to coast melodrama that goes in circles.

reviews.review_title: A decent film about the transformation of a relationship, but it is not a romantic movie
reviews.content: This is a film about the complexity of relationships - how two people can be so deeply connected yet so utterly disconnected at the same time. While the film focuses on a tiny window through the entirety of a decade long relationship, it was a transformational moment, the culmination of years of communication breakdown and growing apart. The divorce lawsuit gave both a chance of reality check - through the eyes of the lawyers and the judicial system, they were forced out of their own narrative to re-examine what happened to their relationship, which roles they played in the sequence of events, as well as how to go forward with the best interest of the child in mind. In the process, they also went from being self-centric and directing emotions outwards, to being more inner looking and empathetic. In the end, decisions about relationships are highly personal and subjective. Good or bad, relationships can never go back to where they were once upon a time. The film captures this aspect of life very well.The actors did a phenomenal job and the music choices are excellent. However, I do feel at times that the film dragged a bit. In additional, beware that many emotional and plot transitions are subtle, yet closely connected. The actors delivered that brilliantly, but not every viewer caught those slight shifts in the details, which is reflected on some of the confusion or frustration about the movie expressed in the reviews written here. It is not a film about romance, or evil lawyers, or parental responsibilities. Unfortunately, the trailer is a bit misleading and some viewers probably had a different expectation going in.All in all, this is a well-made film and I recommend it to people who are interested in movies about relationships that have healthy amount of realism and maturity.

reviews.content: The story is that a great man marries a stupid selfish woman and is dragged through an unfair and painful destruction of his and their son's life. But the storyteller seems to take the woman's side.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful film about the collapse of a marriage
reviews.content:
For me, there are several reasons this film is a 9/10. To elaborate, very few films, only a handful, for me are a 10/10. For a film to be 10/10 it must be perfect, this film was sadly so close but was, however, let down by odd sound mixing at the beginning of the film that lasted for a while.1) The Acting
The acting is superb, some of the best of this decade. Incredible. The crying, the shouting, the slight show of frustration, the happiness and desperation they show to one another over the decay of the relationship. The acting is something that elevates the film to such a high degree and allows the characters to feel very real.2) The Story
The story is well formulated. Now, I am not an avid romance film watcher, thus I cannot say if the story is unique in the sense of talking about divorce.3) The Characters

reviews.review_title: "I want..., an entirely different kind of life."
reviews.content: This is a tough movie to watch if you've been divorced or are thinking about it. And even if you're happily married for that matter. At the same time, the story seems realistic enough that you could picture two people going through this experience with all of it's emotional highs and lows. As a couple, I couldn't actually relate to Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver as characters married to each other. Driver in particular doesn't strike me as the leading man type, but that might have been for the better as the reasons they got married in the first place were eloquently spelled out in the pair's individual letters to each other. My first instinct about Nicole Barber (Johansson) was that she was entirely non-cooperative with the marriage counselor who was trying to help them understand why they fell in love with each other. Writing out their feelings seemed like a worthwhile project, but for Nicole not to share the information seemed quite unreasonable. As the story progresses however, we learn that the give and take in the marriage was pretty much one sided with Nicole doing all the giving, and Charlie (Driver) doing all the taking.Enter the divorce attorneys and the situation takes on a grim aspect. Alan Alda's brief stint as Charlie's lawyer was quite comical actually; his unintentional (or maybe intentional) way of double talking was quite amusing and had a way of driving Charlie batty. The eventual sparring between Nora Fanshaw (Laura Dern) and Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta) managed to negate the intended peaceful resolution to the divorce which had been premised by the Barbers when they first began thinking about it. As for that social worker (Martha Kelly) who called on Charlie and son Henry (Azhy Robertson), well, she looked like she could have used a good intervention herself.The sad thing for the Barbers after the fact is that the marriage could probably have been saved had they allowed themselves the time and distance to come to terms with their situation. Instead, there was no happy ending here in the traditional sense, Nicole and Charlie each went their own way with no sense of fulfillment or closure for either one of them. I could have done without that theatrically inspired ending with Charlie singing to his friends at the bar back in New York. It wasn't particularly entertaining, and if you noticed, no one clapped their approval. Which is kind of the way the story leaves you feeling as a whole.

reviews.review_title: The most amazing movie about divorce ever made
reviews.content: This will be just another movie if you havent lived it. If you have lived this I'm 99.9% positive you cried at least twice if not more. It hits right to the soul. I'm a manly guy who was crippled by this movie. It's just hit on every aspect. Things are just not fair when it comes to divorce. I want to watch it again but I won't. Too much.

This is just my opinion as divorced woman with a child, but does Hollywood always have to present women as villains and horrible, revengeful shrews? Honestly? Even likable Scarlet Johansson can't save this one from being unlikeable, cruel and selfish. I bet they wanted to present her as kind and sweet and reasonably angry and him as cheating ahole but they failed. I mean, I had failed marriage and it was bad, but I didn't have any need to burry my ex in any way financial or other. I understand that someone can be angry about certain things but this was just too much and again it presents women as these revengeful, selfish and unforgivable shrews while men are totally unaware of everything, confused and shocked all the time while she is taking literally everything from him. That is supposed to be "romantic" drama about "marriage"? It's more like Hollywood fake drama about two fake, selfish showbiz individuals who don't love or care for each other anymore so they (mostly her) are trying to hurt each other as much as they can. They tried, oh so hard, to portray woman as kind and sweet and justified, but they failed. Everything she does is just for revenge sake and to hurt father of her child as much as possible and take everything from him. Why? We are never told. It was hinted he had an affair but later we find out it was AFTER she already kicked him out to sleep on couch and they stopped caring for each other. Suddenly after a year of dull, loveless marriage she literally commits a crime by hacking into his account, finds out he cheated (after a year of dull, loveless marriage), and suddenly gets super angry, crushing him like a bug while Adam's character looks like helpless, man-child who is suddenly thrown into meat grinder and can just observe how his life and all the work is taken away from him. Who are we supposed to root for here? It's a 2 hours long meaningless fight with no twists or growth or resolution, just depressing, sad and boring. Yes, performance is good, as is directing but I felt empty and depressed and I watched Vivarium just before that.

Just saw "Marriage Story." A disaster, an embarrassing, schmaltzy excuse for human interest. Despite the two excellent leads, it features at least three despicable performances (and casting choices), including the worst child acting since "Room." Shoddy, ludicrous self-indulgent writing, unbearable set design and cinematography. Many of the key, dramatic, two-person dialogues are shot close up, are stationary, and appear to have been done with the actors in separate locations, which is extremely alienating and ignorantly counter-intuitive. Adam Driver sings - yes, he bursts into song, one of Randy Newman's worst ever! - as if he were CGI'd into the script. This all goes down like American cheese on white bread, soaked in gluten-free L.A. sauce. Noah Baumbach deserves a future directing ED commercials

This film follows a couple how is going through a divorce. Though there is some bickering and fights, the story focuses on what emotions the characters go through. It gives me heavy heart, to see what they have to go through. I can imagine there's still love, but there is even more regret and sadness. It grips me and makes me feel so sorry for them.

reviews.review_title: A wonderful and real Marriage Story
reviews.content: This movie is an emotionally lacerating experience with an incredibly wonderful script and performances. The little moments mean so much through all movie.

Marriage story is very aptly titled. I think it is also kind of a love story. This movie has heart in the right place. What performances. great script, great direction and great camera work along with the music.I laughed. Cried. It's a very intimate film. Very powerful in every sense.More power to the team and a big shout out to the actors. Wow.
I'm speechless. Not only the story is so moving, but acting and especially 'techs' are perfect. I'm going to see it once again.

reviews.review_title: 'Deep' drama that actually isn't that deep
reviews.content: I am in the minority in that I did not get the praise lauded on this film at all. I understood what it was trying to do, it was trying to be an authentic portrayal of the breakdown of a marriage. But it kind of felt like watching a hallmark channel version of this to me. If you are someone who likes to watch 'hollywood' films where there is a disconnect between the real world and the cinematic world, this is a perfect drama for you. You can experience the drama without it being encroaching on the real world. There remains a clear fourth wall for you to watch and observe some emotional drama from behind. But I found that hollywood disconnect unbearable and was really dispappointed in this film. It is my first contact with Noah Baumbach and if all of his films are hollywoodised in this way I will be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Couldn't finish; I found it tedious
reviews.content: I found this film to be rather pedestrian yet in the guise of something more sophisticated. The lead characters seem privileged and entitled. A boring story; almost like a documentary about people I wouldn't be interested in knowing.

Very slice of life. But I don't recognize any of the life that's being sliced. And I am a theater person - who's been through a divorce. There are moments of poignancy, but the film swings between overblown sentimentality and being just plain dull.The leads are dull, the script is dull, and although Ms. Dern and Mr. Alda know what they're doing, Julie Hagerty's over-the-top turn as the mother is like something out of a "Carol Burnett Show" sketch.There's no new insight here about marriage, parenthood, or divorce that hasn't been done much more skillfully in "Kramer vs. Kramer," or in any given episode of "This is Us."

reviews.review_title: Astonishing story about the American divorce system and how it makes it more difficult on those who want to lovingly end their marriage.
reviews.content: It shows how difficult the system makes it to remain a family through divorce. Yes it protects some, but it damages other innocent and well meaning people. It displays both sides very well, and it shows that our system is broken - the system fails under the best of circumstances.I've never been affected by divorce. This movie not only educated me but made me get the feels. It's a must watch with phenomenal acting, storytelling, and directing.
A movie about divorce.... Very long and boring at most parts. Nothing special. Hear acting though.

reviews.review_title: 1 Star is too much for this movie
reviews.content: The positive reviews on here are disconnected rich people who freak out over crap like this. I turned it off after 20 minutes, it is so obviously forced. The relationship is spelled out within two minutes and there's no showing only telling. The grandmother saying 'just because I have a dead gay husband...' was the end of it for me. I can't believe people actually liked it and it's nominated for awards. Wanna watch a movie about WORKING CLASS people who are REAL and MAJORITY? Blue valentine.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful family drama about love, sacrifice and change
reviews.content: A well made drama about family love, sacrifice, denial, conflict, failure, change and acceptance. A very down to earth "real life" film with a very strong script and superb acting by well established actors who were able to showcase their acting skills at a higher level (especially the casts that portrayed the parents & lawyers) due to the good material and directing in this film. Even the main child actor did a good job and looked genuine in delivering his role.The movie portrays the beauty of family life especially the small details of affection and the act of taking care of each other whilst slowly revealing the underlying resentment of unresolved conflict, unkept promises and unfulfilled ambitions, from both sides in the relationship.The movie also has a late 80s & early 90s vibe to it due the hairdos, dress ups, furnishing, sets and the colour tone of the movie even though you can see it is not truly set in those periods by the look of the cars, handphones and other technologies seen in the film. All this done in a good way to catapult your mind deeper in the drama and especially nostalgic for those who were kids and adults during those eras.I think some aspects of the movie pays homage to the film Kramer vs Kramer which was great.

reviews.review_title: Noah Baumbach is so great at making movies on life
reviews.content: Why does Netflix have 3 contenders for best picture? I cannot answer this question but the streaming service proves with this movie why. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson shine in this film of a married couple divorcing. The film starts off with a bang and continues to get better as it goes along. The use of white colors in the background to contrast the dark feelings of the divorce is brilliant. The actors show real emotions and the drama is brilliant. The film's jokes almost all landed with me and I found myself laughing many times during this movie. The divorce lawyers are played in the cliche but in this film it seems to really work. The divorce plays out quite realistically and the ending is quite fitting. Also Adam Driver can kinda sing, who would've thought. This film, like many other from Netflix, is great.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant acting with a super boring script.
reviews.content: I would give the acting ten stars. The script was so slow and tedious to watch. You can make the point that divorce can be difficult, especially with vulture like lawyers, without boring the watcher to death.

Acting was good, story predictable. It's the ugly truth about what happens in way, way too many marriages. Love turns to hate, children get hurt, lawyers get rich......end of sad story. Nothing happens that you don't expect. Not sorry I watched it, however, won't watch it again.

reviews.review_title: Emotional and honest in its affecting character portrayals, Marriage Story is a wonderfully written and acted look into marriage and divorce
reviews.content: Marriage Story is much more about the small actions that are indicative of character than big showy claims, and is so much more effective for it. Even as the story is about how a divorce happens, it's so emotionally charged because we grow to understand what their love was built on in the first place. Driver and Johansson are both absolutely exceptional, and I wouldn't mind at all if they won the two acting awards at the Oscars (especially if Nyong'o for Us and Pitt for Ad Astra don't get nominated, as it's looking). Johansson is particularly electric, showcasing her character's alternating anger and consideration. Baumbach's script is excellent, showing each character's side fairly and honestly, allowing us to empathize with both while never demonizing anyone. It's that honest, human heart of the movie that brings out the unexpectedly caring touches, like the shoe tie at the end, and the unexpected brutality, especially of one argument. It also makes plain the absurdity of the legal system, specifically in divorce, as it cost both of them boatloads of money while severely straining their relationship and not really getting either person what they wanted. In some ways, it feels like a faithful adaptation of a really well-written character driven contemporary fiction novel, where the characters are given space to be understood and where each interaction has such high emotional stakes. Extremely well made from start to finish, the ironically titled Marriage Story is intimate and deeply, honestly sad.

This is an unwatchable movie about complete nonsense that nobody could possibly be interested in. Marriage is a trap for people who can't live outside of society and have to cling to what they consider to be the accepted norm. This movie has nothing to do with marriage.

reviews.review_title: Love and hate a sad heartbeat
reviews.content: "Story of a Marriage" is a difficult film to evaluate, since its core is to talk about the end of a marriage, the American-directed feature Noah Baumbarch is good but it didn't touch me, his sentimentality is strong, especially in the third act, but it is a contextual film, people who have experienced the same trauma will identify more and feel their pain, feeling and anguish at the top of their skin, which I was unable to feel.As the name suggests, "Story of a Marriage" deals with the breakup of a relationship of an established couple and a child, the long brush outlines the reasons for the breakup but focuses on showing the consequences of a breakup, his drama sometimes escalating. too much, and its hatred and ramifications are strange in the very sense established and created by the film, but as already had, its conclusion is beautiful and poetic, a charming third act that concludes and circumvents its errors very effectively.The direction is simple but has an exquisite use of the camera and framing, always highlighting the distance of the couple and opening up to monologues and views, which are always filled with great performances, the whole cast is fine, Adam Drive and Scarlett Johansson has phenomenal chemistry, and both actors are great in their roles."Marriage Story" is a good movie, it deserves and will take some Oscar nominations, but again, it's a very contextual movie that needs a previous viewer experience, those who don't have that traumatic experience, will see the qualities of the movie but will not feel all your sentimentality. NOTE 7/10

reviews.review_title: Impactful realism (with no happy end?). It felt so true!
reviews.content:
I really admire the acting here, it felt so real and true to actual life. There is no classic 'happy end' to this, you get to see 2 sides of the medal. You can understand him and her...
one thing I did not like that much: the film was still made to sympathize with - him. Often we stay in his perspective, follow him as he takes phonecalls from her et cetera. ... yet the film 'acts' like it shows both personalities and motives equally.
To me it would have felt more real if both sides where shown equally.Yet, the beginning of the movie was one of the best parts, the love letters felt - real. All the little things that makes a partner great were named... even if the main characters could not see them anymore at this given time. I know that this part alone defeats the purpose of this film, but for me - that is what inspired me personally for my own life and relationships.Well done (even though it was not my favorite genre).

Relationships are scary, commitments are scarier and marriage is the scariest thing out there. But still the desire and the need to feel secure, wanted and loved takes over us. But do we get everything we want? Everything we need? Or do we just get lost so much in process of security that we forget even who we are?Marriage Story (2019) is one of the greatest gifts of modern cinema. Everything about this movies is humane, real and natural. This movie will make you go through a series of emotions in just 135 minutes. Though I think Adam Driver should've gotten an academy award just for "The Argument Scene" only, Scarlett Johansson's performance can't be taken lightly, the proof being the "Monologue at Nora's Office" scene, for which Laura Dern got her, very well deserved, Oscar. But what really makes this movie what it is, the absolutely insanely brilliant directing and editing. I loved editor Jennifer Lame's work on the 2018 supernatural/psychological horror masterpiece Hereditary and even though I haven't seen any of director Noah Baumbach's films, Marriage Story (2019) is proof enough for me how much of a great director he is, and I'm intrigued to explore his whole filmography. All and all, I've nothing else to say about Marriage Story (2019) except it's absolutely phenomenal and brilliantly flawless.

I saw Adam Driver only in Star wars movies and Kylo Ren is my one of the favourite characters . Adam Driver did a really great job and Scarlett is as good as always.Excellent story narration and adoring characters, marriage stuffs and couple chemistry is really incredible and that last bar scene ......... goosebump performance.Again Adam Driver proved himself an oscar worth actor .
I loved every moment of this beautiful film. The writing, and direction were superb. The cast was amazing, and the music perfect.

reviews.review_title: A Perfect Film of A Divorce Story
reviews.content:
Everything about this movie is fantastic. You can't pause it during watching and you won't feel passing of time at all. Directing and screenplay are perfect. The leading roles performed their best performances. Scarlett Johansson deserves an Oscar for her perfect performance.
It is not actually a marriage story but it is a divorce story. It reminded me "A Seperation" film from Asghar Farhadi but in US society and in another way.
It is the best picture of 2019 among the movies that I've watched so far.
Nominated for 6 Oscars.
10/10. Totally recommended.

Real and sad, Marriage Story will touch your heart and at times cause it to break completely. Moments of anger, sadness, hurt, sorrow and contempt give way to contentment, peace, comfort, and near joy. As we watch Charlie and Nicole fight to find who they are and what they want we discover that the best and worst parts of ourselves bring us together and separate us simultaneously. Ultimately, we work hardest for what we desire most, a place of realization that no one is perfect, not marriage, not divorce, and none of the days that follow either. However we do our best to make the best out of the situation we are in with hopes that we will do better for the next generation.

reviews.review_title: Opinions on 'A Marriage Story', Elites versus the Rest of Us
reviews.content: There is a growing divide in our society between the cultural elitists and normal people. Its the difference between those whos world revolves around life in NYC and LA or Boston and San Francisco and those who live out their lives in ;flyover country'.The wildly varying opinions on this film are perfect example. While then elites see this story as sad, but the 'new norm'. We commoners see a structural problem. We might ask who wrote these perverse laws that allow lawyers to make out like bandits while leaving their clients in debt and acrimonious. We even ask is the ScarJo character even had good reasons to want a divorce from a marriage that seems almost idyllic.People in middle America tend to remain married and consider the best interests of their children and their family, its not always about me me me. People like the ScaJo character think they have something profound to give the world, more often than not, they don't.The delusion of the elites was never more evident than the latest Academy Awards. Its astounding that this film was nominated and even won an award. They are so intellectually and culturally bankrupt that they are scaping the bottom of the barrel. 20 years ago, there would be so many great films that some all-time great films weren't even nominated. Now we get this. Wokeism and delusion rule the day. sad,

reviews.review_title: Maybe this works for married people
reviews.content: I am not married and I don't have kids so maybe I am not the right audience for this kind of movie. I saw it as self indulgent passive aggressive sap. I am giving it a 5 because the acting was actually good and I like the actors in it. However the story itself was lost on me and done a million times before. That usually wouldn't bother me. I don't have a problem watching the same story told in a different way but this wasn't even that. This was the same story told in the same way just with different actors. Basically unhappy marriage. Husband cheats. Marriage explodes. The sticking point is who gets the kid. The one interesting take was the nature of motherhood vs the nature of fatherhood. How a father can act like a complete creep and no one blinks an eye but a mother has to be perfect or she will lose everything. Still this probably only for the married.

The script, score, and direction are amazing but the performances outshine everything. Scarlet Johansson is really really good, but Adam Driver is unbelievable. I've seen many great performances and I'm not exaggerating when I say that Adam Driver's performance in marriage story is perhaps the best performance I've ever seen by an actor or actress. He breathes into his character so much life, and in one particular scene (you'll know it when you see it) I broke into tears because of how well he delivers a line and how believable it is. It's not necessarily the line itself, it's all about the delivery and I truly believe that no other actor could deliver it as powerfully as he did. Joaquin Phoenix was absolutely mesmerizing in joker and should take the Oscar if any other year, but Adam driver gives the performance of a lifetime and will surely give Phoenix a run for his money at the oscars.
If you want to bored to sleep with boring characters, watch this movie. I kept waiting for something to happen. Nothing did. I can't believe it had good reviews.

Very well done movie, great screenplay, great casting. It is like a play. I watched Glengarry Glen Ross recently, and this movie is up there with that. Just good dialogue, acting, story, and editing. I've been through two divorces and this depicts the raw, emotional drama of it perfectly, especially the legal battle.

It's about love, it's about marriage, it's about life itself! This film is too real, too delicate and too cruel for the presentation of life. Although we have tried our best to deal with this relationship in a gentle and slightly lyrical way, it is still shocking. The two lawyers argued fiercely about the play and the long quarrel that followed, which made people sad and heartbroken. From the separation we should consider, gradually evolved into I hate you, must leave you immediately. It's really watching everyone from love to hatred, and even malice to each other, more ferocious.

There is always a dialogue in my mind when I watch a movie: do you know what is the saddest thing in life? Love but not, get but not love. It's not sad, it's just life. When you die one day, what you remember before you die is these, which can be called regret. Then what is sorrow? Maybe you clearly love someone, but you can't understand everything about him, so you mistakenly interpret his kindness as cowardice, his care as stubbornness, his boredom as betrayal, and your two people's past as mistakes. Is this the essence of marriage? The essence of marriage is loneliness. Just like the essence of life, people always want to achieve something, always want to stay with someone, or become someone, but finally they put their whole self into it. Is love destined to be false? There is nothing more real than love, so a person must bear his loneliness alone.

reviews.review_title: Heartbreaking and hopeful at the same time!!!
reviews.content: There have been many films over the tears that have covered the end of a marriage and divorce. Kramer vs Kramer is probably the most famous one but this subject has been covered many times. A Marriage Story presents it in a very sober and matter a fact way. It is presented in a very real way. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver play Nicole and Charlie, a couple with a son that live in New York. Charlie is a theater writer and director. She is an actress that works with Charlie's theater company. When she was younger, Nicole was in a movie that gave her a little notoriety. She lived in LA but when she met Charlie she went to New York. They have decided to separate. They agree to go through a mediator to not involve lawyers but in the mediator's office he asks them to read the good things that they feel for each other out loud. Nicole refuses. She is going to take her son and go to LA to work on a TV pilot. Charlie is aware and agrees with the idea that she and his son would be back not fully realizing the marriage is over. Nicole is living with her mother in LA. Nicole goes to a lawyer in LA and is going to serve Charlie with divorce papers as soon as he comes to visit their son Henry. Nicole can't serve him the papers so she asks her sister Cassie to do it. This film is certainly a drama but their are many funny scenes. Charlie gets to Nicole's mother's house and comes in as if nothing is wrong. He gets along with Nicole's family very well, they love him too. He seems blindsided with the divorce papers. He thought that the move to LA would be temporary and Nicole would come back. Not the case. Charlie feels that they can work the divorce between them without lawyers. Things have changes. The film has alot to say about how people that still even love each other become enemies when they divorce. The most simple things become legal battles with each side's lawyers trying to make each of the former couple look like horrible people. While sucking them dry financially. Nicole's lawyer is Nora played very well by Laura Dern. She is very nice but a very good, brutally effective divorce lawyer. Charlie first hires a lawyer named Bert played by Alan Alda. He is an old style, lawyer, wanting to maje the divorce as painless as possible. He is not strong enough to tangle with Nora so Charlie hires Hay played by Ray Liotta, who us more of an aggressive lawyer for court. There is not much running time spent in the court room scenes bit it is clear that both Nora and Charlie are horrified at their lawyer's tactics at making each them look like horrible people. The maddening thing about this relationship is that it is obvious that these 2 people care very deeply about each other. The relationship is portrayed as being mostly respectful but of coursethere are many problems. As a viewer I asked myself many times why didn't this couple try to work it out? There is a scene that they try to gave a conversation without the lawyers but all of the legal fighting brings out the pent up anger in both of them and they have a horrible fight. Ultimately, things get worked out and both move on. The film doesn't necessarily sude with either of them which is good. The film to me explores the fine line there is between love and hatred in marriage. It's obvious that Nora and Charlie care about each other, but that is not the only thing that could keep them together. The film is hopeful in the way that it portrays to parents that both love their son ho through what must be a horrific process. Divorce.Grade: B+

Great movie. Reallt loved it! Hard to get friends to watch it because they judge the title and rating. But for me it was almost perfect. I thought back of this movie after watching La La Land. They're quite similiar in some ways, only in foundation. Sad, frustrating and crippled are some of the word I would use to describe this movie.-watched alone, crieeed 😂😞😭

Focus is on a family divorce with all the added extras , my only problem is .. who wants to watch a film solely about a traumatic family breakdown and relate to it . I felt so much watching this film and saw my own life flash before my eyes. The acting is wonderful as is the writing and directing. The film honestly portrays the joys and pains of marriage and is an emotional rollercoaster. If you havent seen it you are missing out.

Acting was wonderful and touching and sad movie. But the plot was very thin and it felt like a real divorce case (which was the goal I guess). But it didn't have much of an entertaining value. It gets 5 from me because the acting was very good but the story told in the movie was just sad and boring in my opinion.

reviews.review_title: Not a comedy and not worth the good reviews
reviews.content: Two unpleasant, rich, unbelievable people use unlikely dialogue to be horrible to each other to get custody of the most annoying kid ever.I don't get why it's billed as a comedy drama, it isn't. Not worth the reviews and awards it's been given. I can't really find any redeeming qualities in this waste of two hours.

reviews.review_title: Misleading title but not a bad movie.
reviews.content: The title mariage story presumes that most if not all marriages lead to a divorce, which isn't the case. A more suitable title would have been a divorce story, or something along those lines. The movie itself was filled with a couple of emotions, most of which were draining and depressing. It shows extensively just how much you can lose in a divorce, emotionally, financially, mentally and all the ally's you can think of, which is quite sad. How two people can be so much in love with one another at one point and at another they can't stand to be in the same room, will always remain a mystery.

From performances to screenplay, this film is definitely unforgettable for me. The heartbreaking and emotional feels of the movie, and its occasional comedic touches was so evenly balanced that it really brought out the perfect reaction from anybody who sees it.

Sometimes it literally feel like it's your own family. 10/10

reviews.review_title: Leaves you hoping there is a Marriage Story 2. One of the Years Best!
reviews.content:
I am not a big fan of either of the lead actors but both where fabulous in this trip through a painful legal divorce battle. The supporting cast from Liotta to Dern where perfect and I was trilled to see Julie Hagerty in a nice size role as her mother.
Anyone who has been through the process especially when a small child is involved can feel their pain while clearly understanding that they still love each other. Sometime Life's choices don't work out because both want things to go in different directions. The movie never rushes through important scenes and left me wishing there would be more to tell about this relationship in the future.

This movie is excellent in many ways but it didn't make sense that the couple really couldn't find a way back after the various times there were such strong attempts to turn towards each other. I would have liked at least a conversation indicating that the couple better understood their intractability. Makes me hate divorce lawyers. There are some good ones out there
Marriage story is a certain Oscar contender in several categories, including best film, actor, actress and particularly supporting actress Laura Dern. The film will remind you of Kramer vs Kramer....

A movie worth watching.

Oscar worthy!!

reviews.content:
There is one scene in the movie where Charlie is singing at a restaurant and the song perfectly describes me, I cried then. I cried again when he finally saw the good things she wrote about him.
The entire movie was amazing and super realistic even up until the end which you dont bet an ending on this one, they leave you wandering... we never know if they stay together in the future .

reviews.review_title: An honest film about relationships, divorce, and moving on
reviews.content: I had never seen a Noah Baumbach film until Marriage Story and apparently I have been missing out. His screenwriting and directing are wonderful, the story weaves itself so well and the fact that it was supported by such wonderful acting from Driver and ScarJo made the story that much more authentic. It is an honest look at the relationships we build, the process of destruction and the toll it takes during the divorce process, and the hope of moving on happily ever after.

WHY... Well made, and acted... But, why.. I suppose more importantly why did I spend 2h 16m watching this, albeit well done, movie. It is true to so many levels.. NOTE: IF YOU HAVE LIVED IT.. NO NEED TO WATCH IT.. unless you want to punish yourself all over.

Marriage story is a very accurate portrayal of marriages, especially in the US, having the highest rate of divorces. It's a tough topic to execute but thanks to the very talented people involved in this project, this film feels really well made and will hook you from the start. The writing is tight and thus you really feel the emotions of people going through a divorce. The impact it has on and the way it alters the respective personalities of those undergoing a divorce have been portrayed quite accurately. There's a scene where the couple let out their piled up emotions completely and breakdown is so powerful and engaging. Adam Driver has given a spectacular performance in that particular scene and also Johansson has supported really well. So overall the performances, the writing and the directing are all really well done and will keep you immersed throughout.

This movie is a great character study of how divorce, the divorce courts and the people around the characters can completely change how they feel about eachother. All the characters are brilliantly convincing and well acted. Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson and Laura Dern are all fantastic. It has one of the best screenplays I have seen all year with some truly tremendous scenes. The cinematography is good, with it really centralising the main characters and showing how wrapped up they are in the proceedings, great use of negative space as well as bland colouring so that the actors take centre stage in vital scenes.

Marriage Story is a Drama and by that a god damn great one, it never bored me for its length and the score is great and used in a fitting way.The Characters and how they interact is the heart of any Drama and this is probably the movies strongest point, how the members of this family interact,suppress or express emotions, in such a realistic way, is completely mindblowing to me. There are countless scenes in the movie where the characters emotions are portrayed in such a subtle way and as a viewer you get how they feel, you can see it in their eyes voices etc. and not just cause they cry a whole lot.This amount of character work is portrayed by the 2 amazing main actors Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson, its probably one of, if not the best career performance for both of them.This movie makes almost every other Family or most Dramas in general look shallow and unbelievable dull.

reviews.review_title: Not a fun watch. At all.
reviews.content: Despite the constant barrage of films that are meant to excite, bewilder and entertain, there will always be an appetite for those that feel gritty, real and make you use your brain. This is the case with 2019's Netflix drama 'Marriage Story.'In typical Noah Baumbach fashion, there's a lot to unpack here. 'Marriage' looks at the unraveling relationship between two middle class Hollywood types (Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver) and how they deal with raising a son during a divorce. Unfortunately, this strikes very close to home for many, which is partly why it has found an audience. Unlike the personal dynamics at play here, the plot is relatively straightforward. Just like the flight path between New York and LA (and back) - a typical one for this industry - we alternate back-and-forth like a ping pong match, with Johansson and Driver trading barbs and trying to one up each other around every corner.The real intention of 'Marriage' is to show off the acting capabilities of our leading and supporting cast. While Driver surprises, ScarJo comes off as forced and one-dimensional; the role of Nicole was written for someone who has much better range. And while Laura Dern dazzles as established divorce attorney Nora Fanshaw, she could be accused of rehashing her portrayal of the similarly cutthroat Renata Klein.'Marriage Story' is a long, downward spiral that may make you think, but it also leaves you feeling pretty depressed. Some argue that it's an amazing team performance that should be celebrated, but it's just not a fun watch. At all.

reviews.review_title: Empathy reflected in script-writing, acting and directing
reviews.content: 'Marriage Story' is inspired by the experience of its own director. Baumbach himself has been divorced from Jennifer Jason Leigh and has used his parents' divorce as inspiration for his previous film. He said, "I have a real connection to the material ... but I was also at a time in my life where many of my friends were getting divorced. I saw it as an opportunity to do something more expansive, so I did a lot of research. I interviewed a lot of my friends, and friends of friends, and then also lawyers, judges, mediators." Adam Driver perhaps has shown one of his best performances yet, having most well known for a HBO TV Series 'Girls'.The opening and closing scenes work as sequences and works well together, without giving away the plot of the film. Most of all, this is a film that looks really realistic since it is based on quite a lot of research. People do not have to be married to understand this film as the film will definitely show us how it feels to be main characters, Nicole and Charlie. The film also built empathy for both characters even though they are experiencing divorce. This is something really rare as divorce is often depicted as husband or wife's fault but never both. Here's a review of how the film uses editing for empathy, which really works well with the script-writing, acting and directing of the film.

I don't know if one could say to be surprised by Oscar winning movie, but still I was. Sometimes Oscar winners are pompous crap, but this one was a very good movie. I was surprised by the depths this movie took me. I have no experience about divorce what so ever, but I really felt the pain those characters went through. It was amazing how this movie could make me cheer for both of the main characters, to see flaws in both of them and still wish they both could "win". I think that this was really well done divorce-love story that made the characters very humane and likable at the same time. Those parts when the characters yelled to each other and said bad things were just brilliant. It really looked like actors might have cried between the takes.

reviews.review_title: It has fantastic acting, but does it do anything else?
reviews.content: Hard to rate this one. On one side I liked it, it was entertaining and Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson gave amazing performances, but the characters they play are really flawed. Some of their decisions lack further thinking. I do like Charlie more, but they both make terrible mistakes. I haven't heard of such divorce story in real life like ever, yet many say it's very realistic. Maybe it is realistic in USA, but in Europe it's not. IDK, I think this movie tries too hard to be sad and dramatic and lacks realistic character choices. Kramer vs Kramer has exact same plot yet is much more entertaining and sad and characters are much more believable.

reviews.review_title: Technically Excellent, but not a Feel-Good Story
reviews.content: This movie can be tough to watch at times as it presents a very realistic look at divorce. The acting is excellent, and everything technical about it is spot on. It does not end on a happy note; instead it ends on a 'meh' - which can be very true to life.

reviews.review_title: A film that will make one feel sad and gloom, still the performances and story is direct and honest.
reviews.content: Just watched "Marriage Story" and this film shows that life and love between a husband and wife can be complicated and painful and it's very hurtful when it has to end. In fact director Noah Baumbach based this on his real life marriage break up. This film is really a strong drama about the going down the drain of a marriage between Nicole(Scarlett Johansson) and Charlie(Adam Driver) and they have a young son named Henry and that makes things even tougher.The couple split their time between both coast as Charlie wants to stay in New York with his theater productions, and Nicole wants to go stay in sunny L.A. and be a free spirited actress, yet oddly this is the plan and the best way they feel to divorce and uncouple. And the process is tough and raw actually sometimes painful to watch. Enter the wild cards that being the lawyers to help steer thru the rocky waves. Watch Laura Dern shine as a tough yet smart elegant divorce attorney named Nora.This picture shows how all involved are affected and the damage that a divorce does it's like an ever lasting wound since a kid is involved. The chemistry and acting was great from both Adam and Scarlett yet the wild card was the performance from Laura as she was like a shining queen who sparkled with every take.

Marriage StoryThis was akin to Cat on a Hot Tin Roof without the alcohol and indeed without the hot tin. My mind tells me this "play-like" drama failed to educate, entertain or inform, and just went totally flat about 20 minutes in. I just didn't see any chemistry between Adam and Scarlett and she delivered her part in a needy and pathetic grating accent. The cast was proficient that's it!This was a kitchen sink I just didn't want to see. Their sexless marriage had precipitated a tawdry affair and this had destroyed any trust they had, hardly a revelatory story!In terms of acting the performances were unvarying and very much on the surface, I didn't even like them so I really didn't care how the plot developed. I learned many years ago that if there is no passion at the beginning of a relationship there will certainly be none at the end.I must say after the court case this picked up somewhat where they all said things they didn't mean and then regreted it but it was so forcefully melodramatic I laughed out loud. My favourite bit was the domestic "observation" it was inspired.The over sentimental mush ending was quite absurd after what had gone before.The luvvies may think this is good but I found it tiresome. The best thing were the lawyers Laura Dern and Alan Alda.

reviews.review_title: Well written well acted and heartfelt
reviews.content: The brilliantly-written dialogue and stunning performances from Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson and an equally stunning supporting cast are the highlights of this film. The film had tonal inconsistencies that were I feel intentional to show the ups and downs of the characters' family lives, but there were points where these inconsistencies became a little hard to take. I wasn't a fan of Randy Newman's score which I felt was slightly overused and played at some inappropriate points which took me out of the reality of the film. It sort of loses focus in the middle, but the beginning and end are spot on and very well done. Johansson, Driver and Dern are all Oscar-worthy, as is Noah Baumbach's screenplay.
This one just hurt my heart. questioning reality & life & love

I really wanted to like this movie due to the cast, and the fact that I usually love movies about real life scenarios, even if totally depressing & miserable.But, the story of this film was so lackluster and emotionally manipulative, and it left me feeling that I had been robbed proper insight into what I just witnessed.I felt like it intentionally had a "man vs woman" feel to it, and never had any kind of balance to it, nor did try to meet in between.And how in the world is Laura Dern even considered a supporting actress when her screen time is less than 10% of the movie, let alone enough to be nominated for numerous awards ?All this movie does is show 2 people who have given up on each other, and no longer believe in trying, who mutually make a decision to not make it messy with lawyers, but then the girl, based on the recommendation from a stranger/co worker, goes off and gets one anyway, making everything incredibly painful, awkward, and least to mention - EXPENSIVE.Save yourself the trouble and just go talk to literally anyone who has been divorced, and it will be far more insightful and entertaining than this movie.

reviews.review_title: A raw and emotional tale from the mind of Noah Baumbach
reviews.content: This is a story about relationships, personal struggles, and the sacrifices one makes for their significant other. A raw and emotional tale from the mind of Noah Baumbach. The movie follows two characters, Charlie and Nicole Barber, played by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson respectively. Both characters are complex and flawed, each of them experience their own problems as they go through the process of divorce. I think the movie is flawless and executed masterfully, in terms of direction. I couldn't really find a flaw, maybe a few nitpicks here and there, but most of the time I was glued to the screen because of how well-acted the characters are and how engaging the story is. Dramas tend to be sappy and melodramatic, this movie feels real. This film explores the messy legal side of divorce where all bets are off and everything is a free-for-all, as well as the touching moments between child and parent. You feel for these characters and you want both of them to come out on top. To evoke such emotions is the hallmark of an amazing film. There are intense emotional scenes that just drains you and makes you empathetic towards the characters. There are also calm and moody scenes that makes you reflect on the characters and the journey they undertook. The music was great, very melodic and nice for the ears to listen to. It fits very well in the movie and serves as to set up the tone of certain scenes, establishing a mood and calmness in the audience. Felt very early 2000's, and the movie does have an early 2000's vibe with its aspect ratio and how the story is presented. In my opinion, this film totally deserves the award claims it is getting, it is an emotional, heartfelt character driven story and I totally recommend it if you have the time or in the mood to cry. Movie had me all choked up and I teared up a bit watching it.Rating: 10/10

reviews.review_title: One of the most beautiful and sad movies of 2019
reviews.content: This film for me is one of the best movies of 2019, because it portrays a subject that many people have gone through, divorce.So the movie presents two people, Nicole ( Scarlett Johansson ) and Charlie ( Adam driver), a married couple that is having rough times and are getting a divorce but this make difficult because they have a child. So we already have seen movies with this subject matter that is divorce; but this movie portrays this subject so down to earth, and I don't mean to say that a divorce is an easy process to pass, it is not, it is difficult, painful, sad and can show the worst part of a person, and this movie is exactly like that, we see the character at there best moments but then we see them in there worse. This film works because of the great directing, realistic performances, scarlet just showed some of her most powerful acting that I could feel her feelings.In conclusion , this movie is beautiful, sad, funny and dramatic, all these elements makes this movie one of the best of the year and we're closing this decade with a beautiful masterpiece.

Marriage Story is directed by Noah Baumbach and stars Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson, Laura Dern, Ray Liotta and Azhy Robertson and is about the struggle and eventual split of the married couple played by Driver and Johansson. I love this movie. Noah Baumbach' direction is some of the sharpest I saw in 2019. You can tell he put time into every single detail which for some people might not mean anything or maybe it's so seem less that you don't even notice that it has an effect on what's happening. He does this thing with the movie where in the first half he kind of makes you side with Johansson, while in the second half he makes you side with Driver. You can really see that they are trying to work things out so that they're family isn't torn apart and so that their kid isn't affected negatively. Even if you haven't been through that you might be able to connect. Johansson gives the performance of her career in my opinion as she brings this humanity and vulnerability to this character which many other actresses could have easily not gotten through with the emotion or make her the villain some how but Johansson finds the perfect balance here and could not see anyone else playing her character. Adam Driver gives another amazing performance here. I truly felt for his character as he's getting dragged into this legal mess that is a divorce. I gotta give props to Ray Liotta and Laura Dern who make me hate their characters but still make them so human and understandable. The look of the film is unique with the framing of the film making it seem like it was filmed in a video camera and so does the color in the film. The score too is incredible and I have to say without the music of Randy Newman some the emotional scenes could have felt cringeworthy or unwarranted but thankfully they land. I watched for the third time recently looking for flaws and I could not find a single one. I am going to give it a 10/10

I heard about this film during Awards Season, made by Netflix it was receiving many nominations in various categories at the big award ceremonies, and it was rated well, so I looked forward to it. Basically, Charlie Barber (Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe nominated Adam Driver) is a successful theatre director in New York City, and his wife Nicole (Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe nominated Scarlett Johansson), a former teen film actress, is the star of the company's latest production. The couple is experiencing marital troubles and sees a Mediator (Robert Smigel), who suggests that they both write down what they like about each another. But Nicole is too embarrassed to read hers aloud and they decide to abandon marriage counselling. Nicole is offered a starring role in a TV pilot in Los Angeles, so she decides to leave the theatre company and live temporarily in West Hollywood with her mother, taking the couple's young son Henry (Azhy Robertson) with her. Charlie decides to stay in New York, as the play will be eventually moving to Broadway. Despite the couple agreeing to split the divorce settlement amicably and have no lawyers, Nicole hires family lawyer Nora Fanshaw (Oscar, BAFTA and Golden Globe winning Laura Dern). Nicole tells Nora the full story of her relationship with Charlie, the gradual feelings of neglect by him and how he rejects her ideas and desires. Nicole also mentions that she thinks Charlie cheated and slept with the stage manager of the theatre company. Charlie travels to Los Angeles to visit his family, revealing that he has won a MacArthur Fellowship grant, but Nicole serves him divorce papers. Charlie meets with brash and expensive lawyer Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta) who urges him to fight dirty, but Charlie returns to New York without hiring him. Nora calls Charlie and urges him to get a lawyer soon or risk losing custody of Henry. Charlie returns to Los Angeles and hires empathetic and retired family lawyer Bert Spitz (Alan Alda), who goes for a more civil and calm approach. On Bert's advice, Charlie rents an apartment in Los Angeles to be closer to his family and strengthen his custody case. Charles wishes to avoid going to court, so Bert arranges a meeting with Nora and Nicole. Nora argues that Charlie had little respect for Nicole's wishes to move back to Los Angeles and that Henry would prefer to stay with his mother rather than flying back and forth. Bert privately advises Charlie to leave his New York residency, but a frustrated Charlie refuses and decides to fire him. Using his MacArthur Fellowship grant money, Charlie hires Jay. The case moves to court, where Nora and Jay argue aggressively on behalf of their clients and attempt to portray the other party in a negative way. Nora highlights Charlie's past infidelity and emotional distance, while Jay exaggerates Nicole's drinking habits as alcoholism and mentions hacking into Charlie's emails. Meanwhile, Charlie and Nicole remain friendly out of court and share time with Henry, who is increasingly annoyed with the constant moving. The couple are embittered with the legal process and decide to meet in private to talk things through. The discussion starts calmly and friendly, but eventually becomes a bitter argument. Nicole claims he has truly become selfish, and Charlie punches the wall and says he wishes that she would die. He then breaks down in shame and apologises; Nicole comforts him. Expert evaluator Nancy Katz (Martha Kelly) monitors a night in with Charlie and Henry, during which Charlie accidentally cuts himself. Soon after, the couple agree to reach an equal agreement to finalise the divorce, although Nora negotiates slightly better terms for Nicole, against her wishes. One year later, Charlie play has been a success in Broadway, while Nicole has a new boyfriend and is nominated for an Emmy Award for directing an episode of her show. Charlie informs Nicole that he will be living in Los Angeles full-time to be closer to Henry. Later, he discovers Henry reading Nicole's list of things she likes about Charlie she wrote down during counselling. Henry asks Charlie to read it aloud to him, he does so, becoming emotional as Nicole watches from afar. That evening, following a Halloween party, Nicole offers to let Charlie take Henry home even though it is her night with him. As Charlie walks out to his car carrying a sleeping Henry, he Nicole smile at each other, and they part ways once more. Also starring Wallace Shawn as Frank. Johansson and Driver both give exceptional performances as the separating couple who try to remain friendly through a difficult process, their highlight is the argument, it is good to see Liotta and Alda appear as well, but Dern does almost steal the show in most of her scenes, including a magnificent monologue moment. The title is probably deliberately misleading, as it is about a marriage ending, it gets ugly when the lawyers get involved and the custody battle gets heated, it is well written, with moving and emotional moments, but a little room for humour also, it is a worthwhile drama. It was nominated the Oscars for Best Motion Picture of the Year, Best Original Screenplay, and Best Original Score for Randy Newman, it was nominated the BAFTAs for Best Original Screenplay, and Best Casting, and it was nominated the Golden Globes for Best Screenplay, Best Original Score, and Best Motion Picture - Drama. Very good!

In terms of being a romantic drama, this film is perfect. There's nothing, no choice or decision by Baumbach, no line, nothing, I can complain about. Baumbach crafted a staggering drama, full of love, humor, pain and sadness. It's a film about life itself, about the transience of life and how we spend this time with our beloved ones, how they are part of our lives and how we carry them in our hearts, even if they are separated from us.It's that calm, down-to-earth style, in which Baumbach delivers us his story, with his small parts of humor in it, where you even have to giggle sometimes. It's never too much, it's always on point - and when needed, the film gets emotional. The "argument-scene" in Driver's apartment is probably one of the best scenes i have seen (or "scene" lol) in a long time.With all that composure, that calmness, the film has the ability to be incredibly powerful and move you to tears. I cried, like I nearly never cried in a movie before, asking myself, how a film, how fictitious characters could move me to tears like that. It's amazing to see that movies still have the power to do so and I'm very thankful to Noah Baumbach for creating this great piece of art.

Spoilers ahead!After hearing many good things about this film, and being quite interested in the subject - I've watched it with high expectations. Let me say - this is a very, very honest film. For as long as I can remember having opinion about film as an art form, I cherish movies that bring something personal and human to the screen. Most contemporary films lack this aspect, thus, are almost unwatchable for me. Marriage story is a story about two people who no longer see a reason to be together. Some will argue: oh, but the child!
But, the children we raise to become persons for themselves - not to tie them to us forever. I think many couples forget that. Children will eventually leave home but spouses shall remain together - unless there is no reason. I understood perfectly when Nicole Said: "I will always love him." It's not a romantic love - it's love towards another person - a person with whom you shared a portion of your life, but you do not wish to share bed or dinner every night with anymore. That's life. I've had s relationship that ended this way - the guys was my first love, first everything, but, at one point it didn't make sense anymore. Divorce also happens without "obvious reasons" as some complained that this movie doesn't show us all the reasons. But, when you lose yourself, when you feel like it's about someone else rather than about the two of you, and to feel it constantly, it can be crushing. Had she stayed with him, I can even imagine the flame of envy starting to spark. Obviously she has no strenght to fight, he doesn't feel like he's doing anything wrong - there are no goodies and baddies here. You can argue: she should at least try! Or say: he is too self-absorbed!
In both cases you'd be right - but in everyday life this is what really happens on so many occasions. People will not fight because they've been feeling like this for a long time and at this point they just want their way out.
As you can probably guess by now I think psychologically this film is amazing, what bothers me is maybe too biased ending: her getting Tony nomination (I felt like it's there for pure female empowerment, when art isn't supposed to be gender's maid) and new boyfriend while the husband is moving to work in Los Angeles - I felt like maybe the film had more sympathy to her, but, okay. I guess that's Hollywood's toll on this film: that's what's keeping it too much on the Hollywood terms. I said this is an honest film: it's not melodramatic and romantic, it has many practical and everyday problems, thus, I felt it should've ended in the same manner. Also, it nods to the kafkaesque atmosphere of the courtrooms and legal battles as well as to the modern theatre life, which I think is very cool.
Overall, deserves a watch!

reviews.review_title: A portrayal of divorce that excels.
reviews.content: The sheer brilliance of Noah Baumbach's film 'Marriage Story', surrounding the divorce of Charlie and Nicole Barber, is astounding. Every aspect of this film was well thought out, from the direction to the writing to the sets, with Baumbach crafting his piece exactly as it should have been. The most notable driving force of this movie is the acting - with career-high performances all around. Scarlett Johansson was magnificent as mother and wife Nicole, showcasing a powerhouse of emotion through an incredibly convincing and authentic performance. Adam Driver gives perhaps his best performance of all time as Charlie, so immaculate and raw that I was fully immersed in his character right until the end. Any other year and he should have won the Oscar. The confrontational scene between Charlie and Nicole has stayed with me as one of the most moving and powerful scenes, if not the most, I have ever witnessed in a film. The script was perfectly written and the narrative executed brilliantly on the screen and I found it impossible to be unengaged. I cannot praise this film highly enough, it is an incredible piece of work from everyone involved who went above and beyond. Do not let the synopsis or nature of the story put you off, because you will not regret watching this one.Worth the watch? 1000 times yes, an essential for fans of cinema.

reviews.review_title: Don't understand the low reviews here
reviews.content: The main criticism that this film seems to be getting from the other reviewers here is that the script itself is boring. I just can't wrap my head around why this is what people are criticizing it for. The story wasn't meant to be an exciting on the edge of your seat thriller. It's an incredibly emotional and dramatic story that plays way more on what isn't said that what is. Baumbach paints us a painfully real couple watching the downfall of their marriage. Trying to maintain their own individuality while also balancing being part of a family. Balancing their dreams with those of the people closest to them.Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson both greatly exceeded all expectations and provided an incredibly real feeling that isn't easily obtained. By the end of it, it doesn't feel like you're watching two actors, it feels like you're really witnessing Charlie and Nicole try to figure out their lives.Highlight scenes were: Courtroom scene, Fight scene, Charlie accidentally cutting himself, Nicole's monoluge to the lawyer, and my personal favorite scene; Charlie singing "Being Alive"I seriously could talk about Charlie's singing scene for hours, it blew me away, and it pains me that some of the other reviewers here were not able to feel the same emotion from it that I felt. "Being Alive" is a famous broadway number from a showed called Company. The show focuses on marriage and the pitfalls associated with it, culminating with Robert singing "Being Alive", vocally capturing the effect that finding love can have on our lives. He acknowledges the good and the bad, but mostly the impact that it can have and the way it can make you really feel alive. Charlie singing this in front of all of his friends is absolutely genius and it's scenes like this that make me fall in love with writing again and again. Charlie, a self-made director who's entire life and career is built on just how much he loves theater, and you can tell from the way he speaks the dialogue parts that he knows this play well. His singing is the perfect mix of: someone clearly involved in the arts who's knowledgeable about singing, but also someone who clearly isn't a singer. He's still just the director and he'll never be the lead actor. The pain in his voice and emotion he is able to deliver in just that scene, for me, makes the movie one of the most emotionally moving movies I've ever watched as well as places it up there with some of the greatest dramas to ever come out of the movie industry.Overall, I highly recommend this film. Don't go into this film expecting to just enjoy the story and move on with your day, you have to embrace every aspect of it. Let the emotion of the main characters sink into you. Allow yourself to feel their pain. Let this movie capture your emotions and it will change how you look at drama for ever.

Adam Driver is able to convey a sense of anger and exhaustion in his scenes while simultaneously feeling desperate and alone. This requires unbelievable talent that definitely should not be overlooked by the Academy. Same goes for Scarlett Johansson, who is the other stand out performance in this film, due to her being able to play a vulnerable and still understanding character is truly a challenge for almost all actors and Scarlett pulls it off with aces.If you have been contemplating whether or not to watch this please do, you will watch a beautiful story about family and how families stay together even after split apart.

reviews.review_title: This is not a story. It is a revelation
reviews.content:
Marriage Story
Marriage used to be primarilly a social contract. It still is a contract. It is also "an intimate and personal relationship." Nothing makes you more vulnerable than marriage and divorce and most of us are terrified of this. We deny it and avoid it however we can; but either way we are "hostages to fortune" as Francis Bacon said.The contract between Charlie and Nicole starts out to be that the marriage will be bicoastal. She is from LA. Though from the Midwest, Charlie is more into theatre so we meet them in New York where he has established a successful theatre with Nicole being his usual leading lady. They have a son and Charlie has come to consider them to be a New York family. Nicole hasn't forgotten LA, and she's just been offered the opportunity to star in her own TV series to be filmed in LA, In a two careeer family who moves? Who compromises?Up to this point, it's been Nicole. The original contract has not been fulfilled. They try counseling first. Each is supposed to share a list of what they love about each other. Charlie is prepared with his list and eager to share it. Nicole has also prepared a list but is not able to share it. Baumbach does not tell us why he reveals it to the discering viewerThe hostages believe everything can be settled amicably but inevitably stumble into their mutual vulnerabilities. It unfolds into a shatteringly climactic fight. The contract had not been fulfilled. The intimate and personal is ripping them apart. There is a son. There are custody issues, financial issues, adversarial lawyers exacerbating issues. Nicole in LA becomes alive. Charlie copes.In spite of some reviewer's biases the brilliance, insight. and compassion of Baumbach takes no side. He portrays no victims nor victors. Eventually, Charlie, ironically, reads Nicole's list - to their son while Nicole watches unobserved.They are no longer hostages to their contract. What they are and may continue to be is symbolized in the tying of an unlaced shoelace., Baumbach does not tell a story. He reveals one.. This is the magic of art.Brilliant writing. Brilliant directing. Brilliant acting. Brilliant use of music. It should win many awards, but no matter. I'll wager it will be studied in film schools for years.
