What makes us watch films? We want to be moved, scared, entertained, or simply engaged. At times we achieve catharsis, but in any case we always expect the filmmaker to have something new and interesting to say. Baumbach could have given us a new perspective on divorce or engaged us emotionally, especially given his personal experience, but he failed to dig deep enough.
The problem is that in trying to be somehow objective and presenting the story from both perspectives he fails to explore the inner workings of either character. We see what is happening to them but we cannot feel it. It's like listening to a guy you just met in a pub talking about his devastated love life. You can feel sorry for him, but after a while you just want to get back to your business. The most obvious comparison, Kramer vs Kramer was a bit of a melodrama, but it had something new to say, as it was questioning traditional parental roles. Bergman's Scenes from a Marriage gave us a precise dissection of the ego of its two protagonists and showed us new depths of human psyche. The war of the Roses was as far fetched as it was hilarious, but represented a cautionary tale for all those who do not choose to split up amicably. What did marriage story give us after two and a half long long hours?
We find out that divorcing is not pleasant and that divorce lawyers say nasty things.
The only reason we end up feeling sorry for the couple is that because of their expensive lawyers they are going broke. They are supposed to fight for their kid's custody, but we never really feel their love for the kid. We have to believe that they care because that's what's parents do, but from what I see I don't understand why adam driver simply didn't go back to his life in New York.
As per the acting, to me it looks like good but not outstanding improvisation. Adam driver could pull convincing facial expressions, but he seems to have lost his charm, while Scarlett Johansson tries so hard to deliver her monologues in an oscar worthy fashion but looks like she's acting all the time.
I really don't understand Hollywood's obsession with Baumbach and his partner Greta Gerwig. I find them so dull and boring.
Maybe you have to be a millennial to get their movies.

This is a story that leaves you fulfilled and yet painfully empty. The true nature of a marriage that has fallen apart, with two once connected people now finding themselves adrift from one another. Both Adam Driver and Scarlet Johansson give you fantastic insight into the pain of breaking away from someone you still love very much, and yet have a greater desire to be free from. There are moments that are genuinely heartbreaking (scenes with a dramatic cat calling argument and a song evoking a realisation come to mind). It also highlights how an amicable ending to a relationship can be turned into an even more painful process by lawyers who pretend to care. As with all Noel Baumbach movies, you are in for a rollercoaster of emotions and sometimes question whether you should be laughing or crying. He also creates a story where you don't take sides and simply feel enormous empathy for each party.This movie will rip you apart and yet give you a smudge of hope that life can continue.
Enjoyed this beautiful picture of today's relationship struggles and superb acting.

reviews.review_title: Awful, Uninspiring, Boring faux Hipster drivel
reviews.content: If ever there was a reason for #oscarssowhite to trend, this excrement is proof. I was not expecting Kramer v Kramer, but I thought an Academy Award nominee for best picture, with both acting leads and one supporting lead being nominated as well, could surpass a Lifetime Movie of the Week. I was sorely mistaken. This is a faux emotionally wrought story with very lame situations and awful comedic interludes. Many situations appear extremely contrived while the lawyer characters (all three...Ray, Dern, Alan Alda) are pure caricatures. The dialogue is really bad... "half of crazy is still crazy!". Laura Dern is a likable actress but was nonsensical as the cool, hip, jeans and heels wearing feminist femme fatale lawyer.Zero chemistry between ScarJo and Driver. Awkward mostly. The big fight scene was absurd. The kid actor among the worst in history...Michelle in Full House circa 1992 did it better.Why is this best picture worthy? Awful.

This story is about a creative, married couple in their thirties with a 7 year old son. It starts a happy marriage, but suddenly a divorce comes from the sky. The rest of the film is about the separation process. In particular the emotions that accompany it. But the divorce industry, lawyers like vultures, is also covered.
All very (too) American. The film also takes a long time. Not a topper, but entertaining. Sometimes the leaps in time and situations are not entirely logical.

I have to start off by saying, whilst I am not the biggest fan of Baumbach's work, I am a massive fan of this movie. The movie simply follows a young married couple who live in New York as they go through the hardships of divorce.Marriage Story has moments to make you laugh, to make you cry, to make you angry. You feel the emotions as the characters feel their emotions, all while never siding with either character. You feel like the child of a divorce being dragged from one side to the other, not knowing who to sympathise with and who your allegiance is drawn towards. This of course comes down to Baumbach's trademark realistic dialogue, and the performances of Adam Driver and Scarlett Johanson - they are both wonderfully superb! As a viewer you feel like a fly on the wall in the midst of family engagements and situations you feel like you shouldn't be watching as Baumbach manages to frame such an intimate setting.Do not go into this movie expecting screaming and shouting, with temperatures constantly flaring - no this movie is not like that, in fact it delivers the same punches in a more subtle, quiet, moving manner. However, do go into this movie prepared for the best movie of 2019, as that is exactly what it is.

I just finished the movie and my husband asked if I liked it. I said, it was well done but I don't know why anyone would want to watch it. He said ever? Or more than once? I said I guess more than once. But really it probably speaks to a lot of people. I'm divorced but it played out very differently for me. Maybe for me it was a "what could have been" if we had any money or children to contend with.Mostly I found it depressing, a testament to how unfair custody battles are towards good, involved fathers. Maybe worse in CA, not sure. It's bad enough to live these moments, I don't know about it watching them as entertainment. It offers very little entertainment beyond the good performances. It's more like art, which I'm not that into film as just art.Anyway, didn't hate it, I definitely feel sad after watching it.. and the 10 year old in me just wants to see the main characters reconcile and be happy together even though I know as an adult that's not what the movie is about.

Noah's perspective in telling his stories is something quite valuable, as noted in The Meyerowitz Stories. Finally, watching Marriage Story is a unique opportunity.

reviews.review_title: A beautiful picture showing the hardships of human love an
reviews.content: If you would read no further than this line: this is a beautiful film and you should see it.Noah Baumbach has taken the same ingredients he used for his last film, The Meyerowitz Stories, and has balanced them with more skill, leading to a picture that shines on all fronts .We observe the main characters, Charlie and Nicole, as they go through the motions of their divorce. We watch them struggle with their desires while they try to frame everything leading up to the separation - meanwhile going through all the emotions that bubble to the surface. They have a young child, Henry. Their relationship with him as they go through the break up is redefined, as the parents labor to keep their difficulties out of his world as much as possible. From the film's opening on you are invested in these people and that doesn't change until the end credits are rolling.Adam Driver and Scarlet Johansson are just lovely. I mean, I don't know what else to say. These are two top of the line actors portraying well written characters in a heartfelt story. What's not to like? They make you feel deeply for Charlie and Nicole - their confusion, despair, frustration, doubt and hope, come across as believable and genuine. There will be moments in the film where you will feel their pain, and laugh at their silliness as they try to keep their heads above water.The rest of the cast is a perfect fit, with Laura Dern, Alan Alda and Ray Liotta being particularly good as the divorce lawyers. I won't say too much about their characters or performances as not to spoil the film, but let's just say they represent that side of human nature we would rather avoid having to acknowledge.Baumbach's unique writing style delivers a mix of clever, engaging and sometimes hilarious dialogue and a story that makes the character's feel very real and relatable.This film is a great reminder that right and wrong, in their absolute fairytale forms, don't exist. People endeavor to love and often times they eventually fail. And while that's okay, the suffering that comes with it is inevitable. This picture does well in showing what that means on an existential front as wel as displaying the harsh pragmatical and logistical side of things that comes with a divorce when there's a kid in the picture, without giving us any easy, pre-made conclusions to hold on to.

reviews.review_title: Yeah but I'm in it for the art..
reviews.content: I went into my viewing of this film with the idea that it would be wonderfully acted, that was my one expectation having previously seen several scenes flash across my Instagram feed. The film was. Oh but that's not all...First, there are so many stylistic choices that the director/writers made such as overlapping of voices in tense moments, tempo of action, and an overall mesmerizing choreography, (especially during a scene based around a film set) that make subconscious emotions flood into any viewers head. I loved it.Second, framing by the cinematographer is excellent even when it breaks rules. In fact, especially when it breaks rules. There is a monologue that goes on for minutes, (feels like hours) where, as the dialogue progresses, the camera gets tighter and tighter on the subjects face. Not only does this highlight the emotion of the scene but draws the viewer in and makes them feel the "trapped" perspective of the helpless character. Another particularly beautiful idea was to stick 2 characters in the corner of a room and use the walls to guide the viewers perspective all the way into the corner. Normally this would be a no-no, especially because one of the characters bodies is turned to the camera, however again this illustrates the characters metaphorical position in life, he/she is being backed into a corner and their fate is unclear. Absolutely brilliant!Here's why it's not a 10/10. A. I'm biased against sad movies, sorry I just am. B. There are several lines delivered by an otherwise Oscar-worthy performance by Adam Driver that feel like he didn't even try to deliver them. They fell so flat and ruined some scenes credibility. It made me remember I was watching a movie, (not good).All in all it was a phenomenal experience and I feel like a better person after having viewed it, it puts a lot of things into perspective. This movie is centralized around divorce and I'm fortunate enough to not have had people close to me experience it (yet). Having said that it made me feel a ton of emotions and if it can do that for me, I'm sure it can for you!
Boring as hell, only safe heaven to hide is watching Driver at his best. The director's perspective is fully backing men In divorce sit. with some counterweight scenes to not be very obvious.

Yet I found a one-dimensional law suit drama where a weak and egoistic Scarlett Johansson without personality ruins the life of an Adam Driver with a passion for his kid and the arts. The acting was fine but the writing was lazy. He is the only one who we really get to know, so she naturally comes across as a superficial evil coward. Their child is not really worth fighting over either. So many lost opportunities to make this movie worthwhile!(And right now it scores even higher than the Irishman on IMDb 🙄🙄🙄)

Shocked to see so many 1 and 3 star reviews here, most of the so called critics here are complaining about Nicole's character that she's a selfish narcissistic woman who makes her ex husband's life miserable but they are missing a point here, marriage story is actually a tale about two flawed characters-Charlie who's a self absorbed man who cares only about himself and nicole, a woman who feels insecure and jealous of her husband's success, the critics here are critical of nicole but they don't realise that Charlie was a careless husband, he cared little of his wife's happiness, he hated his wife's home city for no apparent reason despite the fact that she loved to be there, he honestly didn't care about her, he didn't let her direct in his theatre company and was extremely controlling, slowly she starts loathing him but Charlie instead of correcting his mistakes fucks a woman who works with him, sure nicole had her own baggage but in no way she was responsible for all the problems in their marriage, her decision to stay in la with their child was correct, the child needed a family which only nicole could provide, the screenplay is brilliant and adam driver is terrific in this film, it's arguably the best film netflix has ever made

reviews.review_title: An American Separation - inspired from A Separation but lost the humanity
reviews.content: In short, watch A Separation (Jodaeiye Nader az Simin) if you want a similar story, but with a human touch. Apart for the long list of cliches, I think Marriage Story does a great injustice to children. In a divorce, the children are always the ones paying for their parents choices, they are always missing the happy family, they care for their parents and always blaming themselves for the separation. The films fails to show any real emotion of the child, as the authors were trying to feel divorced parents feel good about their children.The only real thing to me were the actors playing the lawyers: Laura Dern, Ray Liotta and Alan Alda. All three had excellent performances, that were not wasted by the script as it happened with the two main characters. The impact of the formal approach on divorcing people's feelings and actions is the only area were this film comes close to A Separation, excepting the unrealistic lack of resentment for the terrible things done to each other by the main characters. But who can complain about realism from a film where the parents have still plenty of energy and time to spend with the child after buying two new houses in LA, without selling the old one from NY, paying the top lawyers and a lot of travel between the west coast and east coast, all while also being successful at work?So, if you want feeling and a film that deserved its Oscar, watch A Separation. If you don't want the effort to think and to read subtitles, then watch this as at least the acting is better than a telenovela, but don't expect a better script.
It's a good movie, not plot twist, nor bombs or superheroes, nor love story, actually a "not anymore" story. And it's good, very good.

I'd rather chew glass than watch this boring, pretentious, unlikable abomination again. Someone please return the two hours that was wrenched screaming from my life. But, if "The Shape of Water" can win an Oscar in today's wasteland, so probably will this pseudo-artistic snoozefest

This movie should be called an anti-marriage story. It was a dry, drab and lifeless movie much like the marriage it portrayed. I rated it two stars for the two stars that were really in the movie - the lawyers. At least they had emotion and presence.

reviews.review_title: Didn't quite get there. Seemed artificial and unsatisfying.
reviews.content:
I had heard such rave comments about this movie, I wanted it to be fantastic. (I don't watch many movies anymore, but this one attracted me by some of the reviews I read). Instead, I found the movie unsatisfying and somewhat boring, actually. I did not feel that the flame war between the divorcing couple (and between their attorneys!) was either compelling or realistic, more annoying and repetitive than anything else. The acting was competent, but a bit over the top for my taste.
The premise: couple still has affection for each other, but there's too much baggage, so they have to separate. They are both intelligent, so it's unbelievable that the wife wouldn't have communicated her dissatisfaction long before, and also that the husband would be so clueless as not to notice there were issues.
They are both overly consumed with getting custody of their son - it's their only important goal apparently. In the real world this could have been worked out as a joint custody agreement, regardless of where the parents chose to live. The first half of the movie seemed brilliant, then it dropped the ball. Nasty fight between the couple and between their attorneys. The guy caves in; gives up his career and moves to LA because his ex-wife wants it. She is an insufferable whiner. And a corny ending of their son finally learning to read at the age of 8 - what, he's a dyslexic? And what does he read? The blurb from the beginning of the movie where the wife wrote down all the things she loved about her "soon to be ex" husband. How cute? Not. A cheap and cheesy cop-out ending.

reviews.review_title: Maybe im the only one who sided with Nicole
reviews.content: The bulk of reviews I have read claim that Nicole was the selfish one and from someone who knows what its like to feel unseen and unheard and want to actually matter and have your own voice, suffocating under someone else's, I understood Nicole's wanting a transition in her life. Most people bash Nicole for bringing in a lawyer into this case but if she didn't do that then she and Charlie would have had to have a 'discussion' which would ultimately be about him getting exactly what he wanted as usual and not hearing, not listening even just once to what Nicole wanted or why she wanted it. I was frustrated that till the end, Charlie, didn't even understand why their relationship went astray and even when she spelled out to him how she felt, he still didn't get it and was in my opinion the selfish one. He was used to getting what he wanted, and Nicole was used to giving in to those. Even when the child told him his own preferences, he didn't listen.I didn't think Nicole was a saint, nor did I think that Charlie was a villain. They both had their faults and I was able to interchangeably sympathize with both at times though I was more on Nicole's side throughout.
Totally mindless. Every line gave me the feeling it was contrived. But it was well produced.
One of those movies you'd play in the background while reading a book.

Scarlett Johansson is mesmerizing in everything she does - performing a role, singing, dancing, and defending her political views, existing, simply. Everything in her is delicately appropriate: the firm, and at the same time, smooth voice; the skewed and hypnotizing eyes, the provoking lips as perfect frames for touching words as "love" and "nostalgia", her performance in the movie built by the way she looks, in all possible senses. The movie begins with a formula: over an assembling of scenes, Nicole (Scarlett) and Charlie (Adam Driver) exchange compliments. We soon realize that it is discourse written in a therapeutic session. They are on the verge of separation, that indefinable, painful, irreparable, destructive, incapacitating moment. Yes, before the rupture, there was love and affection, and this is the most devastating punch at this point. Nevertheless, there is a child and he is going to be used as a manipulative element by both of them, which invariably happens in these cases. There are also the parts' lawyers: Laura Dern and Ray Liotta rock maneuvering the divorce in an indignantly and competitive way. Nicole and Charlie are at that process in which neither of them knows exactly why the marriage failed, and this is disturbing for them and, of course, for us. It seems clear that each other's dimension got lost along the time they spent together, despite (or because) the connections that still exist between them. Scarlett is the physical form of talent, playing a woman who wants the best for her family, but cannot wait anymore to make her dreams come true. Adam Driver takes off Kylo Ren's character and takes the plunge into the role that may redefine him as one of the most talented actors of his time - his losses, after the separation, are shown on his face like Mike Tyson's jabs. The director Noah Baumbach displays autobiographical references in his works, as he did in his best movie so far THE SQUID AND THE WHALE. It is not different here: he shows a depressing trait of the post-modern times, the outsourcing of the sentimental matters, in charge, here, of the two lawyers, who fight over everything that could have been but was not, as once said Manuel Bandeira.

reviews.review_title: Just make people confuse about the plot and get high rating
reviews.content: 30 minutes into the movie and i was wondering what the purpose of this movie to be exist and why its so slow, boring and long.

Like everyone else who saw this movie, I watched it because of the great reviews it received, and the attention it got at The Academy Awards.

reviews.review_title: Not the Best, but Not the Worst
reviews.content:
Personally, I have been putting off seeing the critically acclaimed film Marriage Story directed by Noah Baumbach. People have been telling me to watch this film since December and I didn't really want to watch a film about a divorce around the happy holiday season. Also, I have heard from multiple sources that this film deserves all the awards that it had been nominated for and I was worried that the film wouldn't exceed my high expectations thanks to my sources. They were right, for the most part. I personally did like the film, but I can not say that I would want to watch it again.
Marriage Story is about a married couple that would like to get a divorce. Charlie (Adam Driver) wants to stay in New York and his soon to be ex-wife, Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) would like to move and stay in Los Angeles, they also have a child which just makes things much more difficult. This film accurately represents both sides of a divorce and in the end, you really do find yourself rooting for both sides. I personally think the scene where Charlie (Adam Driver) reads Nicoles (Scarlett Johansson) letter is really impactful to show how much they really loved each other and also why they needed to get a divorce. In the scene, their son Henry is trying to read the letter to his dad and he reads, "He rarely gets defeated, which I feel like I always do." Nicole writes this letter to read to Charlie in the beginning of the movie, but she never does because she says she didn't like what she wrote.
Yes, the film is a good film, but I don't think I would personally see it again. The whole movie is about a divorce and it's almost two and a half hours long. In my opinion, this is not the usual type of movie I would find myself picking out to watch on a Saturday night. At some parts of the movie, it did drag on a bit, but I feel the acting of Adam Driver, Scarlett Johansson, Laura Dern, and many more definitely made up for the longevity of the movie. Noah Baumbach also directed the film, The Squid and the Whale, which is also a divorce story but not nearly as long. There are other movies that are also over two hours long, like Forrest Gump. When watching Forrest Gump, you don't feel like the movie is being dragged out to continue making the same point throughout the entire movie. I think, if maybe the movie wasn't over two hours long, more viewers would be interested.
In the film, Noah Baumbach uses many different techniques especially in point of view and costume/makeup. Throughout the movie, I feel the viewers can really understand how each character is feeling about the entire situation. We get an inside view of how Charlies friends are feeling, how Nicole's mother is feeling, and even how their child is feeling. I feel we really get everyone's perspective towards the divorce and separation. I also feel like we really get to see how the characters are feeling by what color their outfit is in some scenes. For example, in a scene where Charlie gets frustrated and angry, he is clearly wearing red to show the emotion that Baumbach wanted to portray.
I can not say the film, Marriage Story, was my favorite. But I can say that I appreciate the acting and the idea of the film. I just feel it could have been much better if it was just a bit shorter. But, I can say that if you have been through a divorce or you have seen one first hand, you may find this film to be more emotional for you. As for me, I can not say that it is my favorite nor will I be watching it again.

reviews.review_title: A Marriage Story (if marriage is a contract and not a covenant)
reviews.content: The beginning of "Marriage Story" begins with a wholesome timelapse of the couple's daily lives narrated by one another reading a letter of adoration about their spouse. However, the film takes a jarring comedic twist when it's revealed to the viewer this is just the beginning of the couple's separation. This clever opening compelled me to believe the film would be more than promising, but the next two hours would only disappoint. "Marriage Story" is hardly about the ups and downs of a broken family, but rather, a spectacle of downs alone where the complexity of love and heartache aren't challenging each other.For a couple that could within themselves choose to see the good in their partner despite all the reasons corroding their marriage, it's hard to believe they're the same couple for the remainder of the film. The pair, Charlie (Adam Driver) and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson), are only ever able to overcome adversity scarcely when Nicole orders Charlie food and ties his shoe. This inability to rise above created very weak leads that coaxed distaste in the viewer for either one or both spouses. The two characters are overloaded with flaws that are grossly overlooked by their own judgement for the entire duration of the film, leaving them with only a single redeeming quality of wanting to do what's right (with not much motivation to do so). During their separation, neither experiences any genuine growth in their struggles outside of courtroom gain. Once the money and lawyers were out of the picture, the two are able to reconcile and be civil. Not because they worked on themselves, on the contrary, but because if they're not facing conflict that confronts their shortcomings, those shortcomings lie dormant until another issue arises. The film gives a false sense of growth, when in reality that growth was stumped by the characters' self-serving pride.Despite being stagnant characters, Driver and Johansson have pivotal points of evoking emotion from the viewer, such as when the two have an argument in Charlie's new apartment and Charlie breaks down. Johanson plays a convincing mother and estranged wife and Driver truly embodies Charlie's emotions, making him seem more surreal, which made the film easier to digest. However, when Charlie sings "Being Alive" to seemingly vent his feelings in a format he best understands, it became less ingenuous. The longer the scene progressed, quickly it became more of a catalyst to fill the film's desire to be an artistic, Hollywood-esque film, such as La La Land. As for the divorce lawyers the film poked fun at, Alan Alda had by far one of the best deliveries in selling his role that outshined the more superficial portrayals by Laura Dern and Ray Liotta (which is largely due to their stifling characters).Furthermore, the film hints at children being used as pawns in the courtroom, yet the film only allows room for Nicole and Charlie's child to become a convenient chest piece. Their child lacks depth or development, other than a "mommy's boy" attachment that causes a petty disparity between himself and his father. While Charlie and Nicole are trying to convince the viewer that their son comes first, they simultaneously are pushing for their own agendas without regard for their child, leaving their son neglected by both the couple and the script writer. For a character who is supposed to be so important to the parents, the character is treated as Waitress #2, and made ironically irrelevant to the story as a whole. Inadvertently, the boy becomes an accessory for the sake of the plot. Unfortunately, the poor development of his character made him quite unlikable, alongside his parent counterparts. In Charlie and Nicole's child, you'll find only the remnants of an idea rather than an individual, resulting in an unmemorable character whose name no one remembers (it's Henry). In this boy I see so many missed opportunities to explore the confusing pain of feeling divided between two people you love and the misguided guilt of driving them apart. In the end, you'll discover two parents who seem to care deeply and sacrificially for a child who's nothing more than a puppet who wishes he can be a boy.Overall, the story wasn't strong. The characters danced around each other and had terrible communication just as the plot did with the viewer. "Marriage Story" is a sensualization of divorce written from a Hollywood-skewed perspective of marriage.

reviews.review_title: A hate letter to Los Angeles
reviews.content: Do you want to hate Los Angeles? Then come here and do all of the cliché things that tourists do such as walking down Sunset Boulevard, and go to Universal Studios. Hey, on the weekend, just switch states and check out Vegas!Do you want to love Los Angeles? Go on a hike up through Will Rogers State Park and see a performance at the Walt Disney Concert Hall. Stay in California for the weekend and spend it in Joshua Tree.Another way to hate Los Angeles is to watch this film! I'm a native of LA; I've traveled the world and I live here again. I love my sprawling city, but this film made me want to leave forever and move to Manhattan.Such typical east coast snobbery here, the shots of NY included the esoteric theater (or should I say theatre) company and the jazzy bar where the pretty girl you know is signing a tune... it was so romanticized and hence saccharin. The shots of LA were mostly of Adam Driver's character having a miserable time in a miserable apartment, surrounded by gritty mini malls. These places exist as part of the tapestry that makes LA diverse and interesting, and yet there is so much natural beauty too.Geographical diatribe over, the film packs a powerful performance punch by Adam Driver. I did side and sympathize with him while interestingly my husband found the culpability rather balanced between the two main characters. Thumbs up.

But somehow for this to be rated over on average as an 8 is a little high in my view.The story is a little too predictable and the ending does not give you much satisfaction. It is littered with several liberals, let's say, propaganda which to me kind of takes away from the artistic side of the movie a little bit. But hey you can't watch a film these days without some political nuances or liberal or conservative propaganda being injected forcibly these days.I love many sides of the movie but in the end it's just what you would expect from a drama about divorce with a kid stuck in the middle. It was quite a lot more focused on the wife's side of the story, making you think that there is a lesson to be learned intended to be for men more than for women. But there were moments when the film was trying to show the shortcomings of the wife too but did not go on bringing the balance required for this to be a complete story.At the end part the ex-wife had found another man and the husband was made to look like the losing party by being single. The wife was nominated for an Emmy for her directing skills, so she is actually the one that is more talented than the husband, telling us all that she had the last laugh and once again another strong indication that it was the husband who is to be blamed and the one who screwed the marriage up by holding her back all this while and not helping her find her own thing in life other than being a supportive wife.
There was also a scene when the husband was seen to have badly cut himself but again I can't tell what it is about, there were scenes of this nature that you can't quite piece it together other than making the audience realise that this is all the husband wrongdoing.However there were some attempts to show some balance. The wife was not all free of fault. During the scene where the big argument took place in the house, the film brought us some insights into the wife sort of neglecting the husband and also sucking the joy out of his life, indicating that women can take the fun out of everything but in the beginning she was described as being the fun one who loves to play all the time. The argument ended very abruptly with the husband screaming some very unkind words of wishing her to die. There was however no follow through on the mistakes or shortcoming of the wife in their marriage for this story to be balanced in the later part of the show. I get it that the world wants to think that men are often oblivious to his surroundings in a marriage and are not sensitive enough to their wives needs, so there is an element of feminism too which as I said takes away from the artistic side of the movie.In the end I felt the ending was too compressed and rushed. 2/3rd of the movie could have been shortened for the ending to give the story a better balance of highlighting what both parties did wrong and how viewers of gender can learn from this story. I felt this movie should not try to masquerade as a marriage story as it takes two to tango. It should be 'An Ex-Wife Story' or something like that.However from directing and acting, wow, just wow. Johansson was at another level altogether, a truly versatile artist. Apologies for the typos/grammar...had to share this views within short amount of available time.

A bittersweet comedy about an marriage that is changing, but not ending. Actress, Nicole Barber (Scarlett Johansson) and husband and establish play director Charlie Barber (Adam Driver) work through a coast-to-coast divorce as Nicole pursues a Hollywood acting career. Marriage Story focuses on the struggle of changing dreams in life and in a marriage. Compromise is something not negotiable for this couple. The couple fights to find what is best for their son, Henry, as their lawyers fight to make Nicole and Charlie the enemy. Marriage Story, a Netflix original, gives the story of an established New York couple who works through marital problems in their own way.
The theme of this film is change. Change can come in many different forms and it can define someone's character by how they react to the world changing around them. In this film, Nicole and Charlie are going through a pretty serious divorce, a divorce that they did not see in their future. But, was necessary because according to Nicole, Charlie was a control freak of their marriage and never really listened to what Nicole wanted. There were many different factors that caused their divorce and the elements of the divorce causes some serious changes in this family of three. Change can be difficult for some, or a necessity for others, but how you react can often define who you are.
This film uses many techniques to make this film as great as it really is. The use of lighting and dialogue make this film. When in New York, the lighting of the film seems darker, giving that depressive East coast feel, while in California, everything is bright, representing new hope and happiness the sunshine gives. This is important because it shows the difference between the two cities and it also goes to Henry's emotions of his living situations. Henry was born in California, but grew up in New York. Once Nicole moved back out to California, Henry was happier, found more friends at school, and was around his cousins more than he was in New York. The lighting of these scenes help show Henry's happiness and how he thinks his life is better in California. Dialogue also helped created the emotion and intensity of the film. One scene that relied heavily on the use of good dialogue was the scene towards the end of the film where Nicole and Charlie were yelling at each other in Charlie's California apartment living room. They start off discussing what is best for Henry because during the divorce, they had moved away from the well-being of their child. This scene develops into a heated yelling match about all the things that they see wrong with each other and how their marriage did not work. Without the words said from both Charlie and Nicole, this scene would never have had the impact it did without the use of strong language and good use of dialogue. There were plenty of other film techniques used in this film, but lighting and dialogue were the most effective.
Marriage Story depicted a couple living the dream in New York until they were not anymore. Nicole and Charlie Barber were a successful, play producing couple, until Nicole wanted to change her career. Things went downhill when Charlie did not support her like she did for him all those year. This film was a story of change and how the characters responded to that change.

Marriage Story was easily my most anticipated film of the year and it met all of my expectations. Essentially every aspect of this was done perfectly. While this isn't my favorite Scarlett Johansson performance, it's a pretty fantastic one at that. Both her & Adam Driver easily give some of the best performances of the year. Laura Dern, Ray Liotta & Alan Alda were great as well.Behind the camera, Noah Baumbach isn't doing anything mind-blowing, but this movie never looks dull. It always looks beautiful, like a classic film in the making. The music from Randy Newman was also amazing.I genuinely don't know how this could've been executed better. This could've been another forgetful Oscar bait movie. Instead, Noah Baumbach delivered a truly substantive film that people will talk about for a while.

reviews.review_title: Kinda stunned of most males reviewing this movie

There is something about this authenticity he brings to his roles that is very special.SPOILERS!!!After viewing it I am amazed how many men have reviewed the movie that say they sided with Charlie from the beginning and never swayed back and forth! I watched it with my man so luckily I know not all men have the same lack of emotional empathy. I as a woman swayed back and forth and tbh I say you must be a woman hating if you couldnt see it from her point of view ever.Believe me, if it was a movie where the roles were reversed - and a male gave up all of his personality and life to cater to a woman's dreams for 10 years, where the man moved away from his family, was being critiqued by the woman in the way he acted, even had his hair and the woman asked the man to put whatever money he made into her dream - AND then she cheated on him AND then she expected him to praise her for all the men she didn't have sex with while she had the chance...you would NEVER see any man feel the least bit sorry for the woman being forced to then give up her dream and have to actually also adjust so the man could find himself and be close with his family where he came from.So. If you seriously never ever swayed to her side - there is something wrong with your emotional range and the way you view women.

Instead of "Watch me act!"Can Hollywood PLEASE stop writing movies about Hollywood and spoiled actors/directors? Do you not realize that there are actually people with careers & lives off the stage and screen? Or is that now the only way you can win Oscars?Like others, I was surprised at how one-dimensional this was. And how poorly written some scenes were.Also, if you are going to pay homage to another movie in your soapbox rant (Kramer vs Kramer), it's OK to mention it. This was supposed to be real life. I'm looking at you Nora/Laura Dern.Instead of watching this movie, read "State of the Union" by Nick Hornby. That actually *could* be titled "Marriage Story." And is far more nuanced.

I watched this movie with my husband and the very high rating of ofcourse lead to high expectations. Unfortunately, the movie didn't live up to those expectations. Yes, the acting is great, but you don't really build a connection with any of the characters. Even though a lot of effort is put into the dialogues, it still feels like you never really get to know them, and therefore, you don't truly root for them. We watched it without any background information, so we were hoping on a marriage revival, but this never happens. You don't even see them make an effort to save it, despite the very touching letters they wrote about each others qualities in the beginning of the movie. For me, the movie was interesting while I believed there was still a chance of them making it better. That a deeper layer might be touched, instead of all the superficial lawyer stuff. (Which was amusing, and sometimes uncomfortable, but nothing more than that). However, it's all about the breakup and therefore, 'Divorce Story' would have been a better name. I cried while watching Mrs Doubtfire (also a dramatic comedy about a divorce, and a father doing anything to see his kids), but with this movie: not a single tear, not even close. The difference is: in Mrs Doubtfire, you could actually truly relate to the characters and their motives, their pain, you get attached to them as a family and as individuals. Marriage story didn't do that for us at all and I'm sure I've forgotten about this movie in 1 or 2 years. I'm still not sure what this movie wanted to teach us, if anything.

Fabulously portrayed and acted.  Really compelling.  What I hate about it is that it doesn't offer any proactive effort on the part of either partner to save this family.  That is almost always a possibility, and by far better than just going on to the next relationship as dysfunctional people.  I mean, we're all dysfunctional to some degree; the challenge is to stick with it, to seek answers, to learn to be unselfish, to learn to accept and validate...and to become always more functional.  It is possible, I know by experience.  Why not go for "alive" at all costs?  Why not seek healing?  Why not act like adults and let the child have as functional a childhood as possible?  There is a lot of good stuff out there - the Gottman Institute for one - it would be completely plausible for two intelligent, warm, real people to seek reconciliation and to always be glad they did.  Instead we have to nod to the prevailing weltzschmerz and go on singing our sad little tune.

Noah Baumbach seems to want to present us with the story of how a divorce could be if both parties tried their best to be amicable whilst, at the same time, fighting to be who they want to be as people. The result is a somewhat odd blend of tones, light and humorous at times, and then suddenly dark and bitter. You might think that sounds kinda realistic, but the reality is it feels a bit… off, like there aren't a lot of powerful moments because of Baumbach's conscious effort not to take it too far in either direction. That being said, there are a few moments that hit exactly as they should (there's a fantastic argument scene) and I found that the film worked best when it explored the stronger, raw emotions of the individual characters – love, hate, anger – instead of documenting the process of divorce itself (lawyers, houses, money etc.). As for the performances, they're solid all around, but it's Adam Driver that steals the show.

To call Marriage Story "Kramer versus Kramer 2.0" is an insult. Not for the reason Kramer vs. Kramer is not a masterpiece, but because these two films are more different than similar.

Marriage story doesn't just succeed at tapping into your emotions. Noah Baumbach found a perfect way to show the life, the process, and the pain of two people getting a divorce. Whether it is in the production design where a scene is taking place, an unforgettable line in the screenplay, or the lovely score in the background. It is unique in the way of showing the anger and hate being overpowered by the love and friendship between these two people. This is brought to life by the remarkable performances of Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson.

To also judge this film just by the fight scene Film Twitter turned into a viral meme is a complete disrespect to the film itself. It is the minor scenes where we are impacted most, such as:

- Charlie does not know what to order during the lawyers' meeting 
- Charlie waiting for his child on Halloween, falling asleep on the couch dressed as Frankenstein in the process.
- Nicole rushing to her room after talking to Charlie and breaking down into sobs from pain and anger after a small argument. 
- Laura's Derns iconic 2 minute monologue about the standards and pressure society puts on mothers compared to fathers (where after viewing that scene, I immediately knew she had the Oscar).

These scenes are what make the film more beautiful and heartbreaking. Rather than just seeing five minutes out of the 2 hour and 17 min. runtime, experience all its beauty completely.

Marriage Story - 9/10. Marriage Story is a story that has been done before. But what makes the film different from other divorce films such as Kramer vs Kramer is the use of comedy and creating a lighter visual experience. Don't get it wrong though, Marriage Story is a sad film overall, but it's the comedy that helps alleviate the pain of seeing people fall out of love. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver do a splendid job of digging into their characters and providing growth throughout the duration of the film. They display a variety of emotions and play their characters in a very grounded nature. Laura Dern is a definite standout as the cocky but well intentioned divorce lawyer for Scarlett's character in the film. Azhy Robertson, who plays the son of the couple, does a great job of playing the child who just can't seem to grasp the magnitude of what his parents are going through. The real star of the movie however is definitely Noah Baumbach. He delivers a story that could have been dreadful to watch, but provides it in such a way that by the time the movie ends, it leaves in a bittersweet mood. "TAKES MY BREATH AWAY" LOVE FILMS
by Timothy J. Verret

I'm as drawn to love films as a beautiful and majestic horse is drawn to water. I create so much about and from the notion of love that it sometimes is hard for me to take a decent, deep breath. Here are 10 (actually 11) films about love (or the lack thereof) that "take my breath away" and heal my still-sometimes-very-broken heart (BOTH!):

1. SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE (1998):
This would indeed be my all-time favorite love film because it's got Shakespeare and it's got that message: "Love is the ONLY inspiration." This film is inspired by a great and awe-inspiring love for acting, writing, directing, and how passion engages all of these things in one love film. Even if this film was not an ode to why Shakespeare wrote sonnets in the first place, the scene where Viola is onstage in a staged production of Shakespeare's ROMEO AND JULIET and William is lovingly looking at her from the wings is more than enough of a reason why I adore this love film. Viola loves William, William loves Viola, and the music takes us away to just this one moment of two looks and two smiles all looked and smiled in the name of a beautiful, all-encompassing love. That scene alone "takes my breath way" every time I see it. Even though this film is #10 on my all-time favorite films' list, it is solidly #1 on my all-time favorite love films' list (I guess you could say, "so the last shall be first, and the first shall be last" [Matthew 20:16]). 😉

2. SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE (1973):
Swedish director Ingmar Bergman is not known for gushy and silly love films, but this film IS a very serious love film because Bergman gives us both the glory and grime of a marriage dissolving. In true and typical Bergman fashion, each scene of this film is a very serious "take my breath away," because the truth and turmoil at the heart of this marriage ending are about as real as my hand in front of my face. Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson as Marianne and Johan give towering performances. I will never forget the scene where Marianne and Johan go to the lawyer's office to sign the divorce papers and literally get into a fist fight. After the fight (and the marriage) is over, they both with their tattered hair and hearts sign the divorce papers. This film is as stunning as it is sacrificial. Marriage IS sacrifice and when that's not there, stunning is any marriage's dissolvement. I probably could have listed a handful of Ingmar Bergman films that explore the theme of this kind of intense love, but I have to keep this list as brief as possible.😉

3. MARRIAGE STORY (2019):
Very much like SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE, this film is haunting and often horribly uneasy to sit through. Scarlett Johansson as Nicole and Adam Driver as Charlie give exceptionally riveting performances as a married couple with way too big egos (she is an actress and he is a theatre director and if that's not "way too big egos," I don't know what is). I will never forget the scene where Nicole goes to Charlie's apartment and they are in the throws of so much anger and so much hurt that the walls of Charlie's apartment are about to come down. Johansson's Nicole delivers to Driver's Charlie the line that is THE line where love hoped to save this marriage and love can't save this marriage intersect, "You're so merged with your own selfishness, you don't even identify it as selfishness anymore!" That line "took my breath away" because I totally identified with it. A marriage on its way to a divorce is all about selfishness unidentified anymore. The proclaimed egos of both partners "win out" and when ego "wins out," everything is "lost in" a marriage war of two "way too big egos."

4. THE DANISH GIRL (2015):
It's so cool that this film is #4 on this list, as #4 is my spiritual number. It's also cool that this film is #4 on my all-time favorite films' list, as well. The story of Gerda and Einar (Lily) Wegener is what love films should always be about: The sacrifice one partner needs to make for a marriage to survive (often times in a marriage, both partners have to make sacrifices). Gerda makes the ultimate sacrifice by accepting that her husband, Einar, believes he is a woman and wants to have an operation to become Lily, the woman he always was on the inside. Anyone else that I can think of in Gerda's position would have said in response to this, "no way, no how….this marriage is OVER!" Gerda loves Einar so much that she is willing to do just about anything (and she does) to keep their love alive. Alicia Vikander (Oscar winner for Best Supporting Actress) is an absolute and complete revelation in her performance as Gerda, and Eddie Redmayne completely and totally seals the deal in his performance in this film to make him my all-time favorite actor next to Joaquin Phoenix. I swear I could go on and on about how this film "takes my breath away" at every twist and turn where love is concerned but, once again, I'm needing to be brief here.😉

5. YENTL (1983):
Very similar to THE DANISH GIRL, this film is not your conventional love film. It's about a woman who loves this man who thinks a woman is a man, this man who loves another woman who is also a woman but since he can't have this other woman, the man asks a woman to marry this other woman so he can be close to this other woman, and a woman who this man thinks is a man marries this other woman, and if none of that "takes your breath away," I'm not sure what ever would! This film "takes my breath away" because it's simply about the lengths and heights and depths we find ourselves reaching for in the throes (or thrown) of love. And because I am a huge Barbra Streisand fan and this is Barbra's best film EVER, I can't think of any other love film that pleases and excites me more than this one. And never mind that it is mainly because of Barbra Streisand and my love for her that helped me to believe that I could ever be someone someday who could love someone someday. Now, that "takes my breath away."

6. WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? (1966):
While most in a million years would never call this film a "love film," I do because it's a film about the absence of love in a marriage, the absence that is SO common in a lot of marriages, and an absence so penetrable that the married couple in this film actually make up that they have a child to keep the marriage bearable. Edward Albee's play and Mike Nichols' film adaptation are what I love most about stories where love has flown the coop (if it was ever in the coop in the first place), i.e., the dissection and probing of the insides of people who are losing their identity because love has become nonexistent while brutality and mean-spiritedness are what's left to exist. Elizabeth Taylor, known for her striking beauty, goes from "riches to rags" in her physical beauty and gives us an "ugly" Martha, a force of nature who is as forceful as she is vulnerable. Taylor, Best Actress Oscar winner) gives what I consider the very best female performance ever captured on film. Richard Burton as George and George Segal as Nick are also excellent, but it's the other female performance of Sandy Dennis as Honey (Best Supporting Actress Oscar winner) that makes this love film truly one that "takes my breath away" every time I see it….and I've seen it a lot!😉

7. TESS (1980):
If there can be any love film that is truly lovely to look it, it would be this film. Based on Thomas Hardy's classic novel of the same name, Roman Polanski directed this film that makes the novel come breathtakingly and beautifully alive. This film "takes my breath away" not just because it's pretty to look at but also because it is rapturous and daring to expose seduction between a man and a woman as actually rape, and how that one act of domination produces shame that stays with the victim. I know that one's shame is to be nailed to The Cross of Jesus but for some, death is the one way, and maybe the only way, to be rid of that shame. Nastassja Kinski as Tess might not be the best actress who ever lived, but Polanksi knew exactly what he was doing by casting her in the title role. Because Kinski was a relative unknown and maybe because Polanski knew she wasn't the greatest actress around, it was precisely these two very things that allowed Kinski to inhabit Tess as bright-eyed innocent, and naïve. A well-known and a great actress would have destroyed these precious traits, so thank God Polanski and Kinski didn't. There's one scene of a closeup of Tess with the brightest yellow sun behind her that to this day, every time I see a sun like that, it "takes my breath away," and I call it, "the Tess sun." LOVE THAT! ❤️

8. THE WAY WE WERE (1973):
It certainly makes sense that I would have two Barbra Streisand films on this list but even if I didn't love Streisand, this film would be on it anyway and probably most others' "love film" list. It's the ultimate love story of the girl over there and the guy over here and how there and here come together and we are all the better for being present to witness that. The odds are that two beautiful actors like Redford and Streisand couldn't possibly go wrong in a beautiful love film that ends with a closing scene that still "takes my breath away." Streisand's Katie and Redford's Hubbell are looking at each other after having separated when famous Streisand takes that famous hand and famously brushes away that famous hair from Redford's famous face. "See ya', Katie." "See ya' Hubbell." See me balling my eyes out.😥😥

9. CASABLANCA (1942):
While not the film I would have included on my "take my breath away" love films' list, I'm including it because it's on the top of the list for two of my favorite people and because any film with an actor or actress with the last name of "Bergman" should be on any film list I compile (see #2 for that "other Bergman" film). That said, I have seen this film and I remember loving it very much. Many "love film" aficionado's are divided into two camps where this film's ending is concerned: One group wants Rick to let Ilsa board that plane to Lisbon with Laszlo for The Resistance, while the other group says, "C'mon! Rick and Ilsa forever! We're not talking about The Resistance here! We're talking about love!" This film reminds us that love doesn't always end as victorious as The Resistance, but what we cannot "resist" is that we loved in the first place. That is usually enough for any kind of love to take flight.

10. IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT (1934) and SOMEWHERE IN TIME (1980):
I admit I was torn between which of these films to include to round out the top 10 "take my breath away" love films, until it dawned on me that both films have something very much in common: The element of time when and where love is lost and/or found. IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT is simple enough to say love can happen one night, whereas SOMEWHERE IN TIME says one night is fine, but true love cannot be contained by the element of time. Love can happen one night, sure, and then more nights can happen after that, but sometimes you have to go "somewhere in time" to find that love again. Whether one night or "somewhere in time," love alters us to our very core and we do search time and space to find it, but there are no guarantees that the Jericho Walls (reference to the ending of IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT) will stay up or come down when love happens in just one night or "somewhere" outside of space and time for a lifetime.

Now, I'm not currently in a love relationship (unless you count Jesus) but if I were, my partner would need to have seen AT LEAST one of these films. If not, watching AT LEAST one of these films is essential if any partner who loves me expects to "take my breath away." 😉❤️

Like all Noah Baumbach's films, I'm split on it. It seems like it is heartfelt and thoughtful, deep, enlightened, warm, complex, philosophical---but after viewing I feel like I've been eating potato chips rather than having a substantial nourishing meal. Clearly he's talented and not stupid. The writing is fine. He has directorial skills. But there's a superficiality and faint whiff of nihilism around him that you won't find in, say, Wes Anderson,  Richard Linklater, Jim Jarmush. And while someone like Scorsese is nihilistic he (a) struggles with that and (b) is unabashed about it. Something about Noah Baumbach's posturing about being humanistic gets up my nose. His work is carefully crafted but, to me, ultimately somewhat hollow--possibly because most of his work is about himself, thinly veiled to be about humanity and the human condition but ultimately his own view of the world and humankind arising directly from his own lived experiences---passed off as insightful, but perhaps just under the surface lurks semi-smug self-preoccupation and narcissism. Rendered---but not created. He's good at what he does. tho. And performances from all the cast are outstanding.

In short, it's a tiresome and dull look at a crumbling marriage.  Noah Baumbach was extremely lucky by the generous reviews and acclaim he has received from this film. 
From a filmmaker's standpoint, this film was many notches below Scenes from a Marriage by Ingmar Bergman or Kramer vs. Kramer. A Marriage Story was too derivative of what we have already seen and there were no exemplary traits that made it stand out from the films that came before it. It was self-indulgent and visionless. When thinking back on the film, there is one scene that comes to mind that stands out but is not distinct. The scene, which is the most talked about, takes place in the very drab apartment where they let out their emotions. This scene felt like a rehearsal or improvised exercise for actors rather than a cinematic, well-written scene where the words make you feel. Rather, it was the actors doing their jobs well, with the wrong dialogue. The writing gives me no reason to feel empathy for them.
The apartment was an accurate portrayal of a typical badly designed apartment in LA but the realism of it was uninspiring and bleak. Sure, that could have been the point and probably his intention but is realism and bleakness what we need in cinema? Where are the days when films felt like an escape and not some depressing rollercoaster through a dismal life? It would be one thing if Noah Baumbach wanted insight into these kinds of relationships from a sociological standpoint and was an upbeat positive person (the opposite of the characters), but he is in fact just taking from his own sad experiences that frankly have been done far better and don't deserve this type of attention. 
Overall, there was an unnatural feeling to the whole film that placed oneself in between a film and theater and an audition room. I appreciate some of Noah Baumbach's work but this one was a miss for me, he can do better. Unlike the Meyerowitz stories, the casting was off and although the actors performed well, I didn't believe in their initial reason for being together or their cry-baby emotions that felt contrived. 
My last question is, who cares about some random couple in LA going through a divorce? There are more important stories to be told that involve realism. Noah Baumbach, stop being so self-absorbed.

This is such a beautiful movie! While it is clear from the start that the movie talks about the separation process of a couple, it is trully able to tell their whole marriage story. It tells you how they met, when and why they fell in love, what started to feel wrong at some point and what lead to the break up, all that in a very sutil way (while it feels like just a divorce story is being told, maybe no such story can be told without describing the whole relationship). It does not try to convince you that they might get together and play with your expectation that they will do so at some point, it is mostly interested in "studying" the feelings and actions of a divorce. Nicole and Charlie love each other. They do have problems, they do seem confident about their decision of divorcing, they do get too involved in the process but, in the end, they love each other. Right from the very first scenes, the incredibly beautiful descriptions each character makes of the other already shows how much love and care is still there. This is such a rich montage in my view, not only for the beautiful soundtrack and the rythm of images but for how it is able to describe the characters and also show how they view each other. Charlie already seems to be more critic while Nicole almost worships her husband. The movie shows the divorce process in such a raw and real way, making it so clear that there will never be a true winner in this case because they love and care about the family; any result will feel like a loss. Things escalate without intention, what also sometimes seems unavoidable in a situation full of tension and misunderstood feelings. There are several powerful scenes besides the initial montage: the long conversation that turns into a fierce argument (the only one in which feelings are actually showed), Charlie singing Being Alive with an excruciating amount of feeling, Charlie reading a book for his kid lying at the same bed in which Nicole weeps at the side, Charlie and their son reading the initial letter wrote by Nicole. This is a sad, soul-crushing experience but that feels extremely real and shows with precision the complexity of feelings and events surrounding a divorce. I really loved it.

The music was beautiful and it was one of my favorite parts of the movie. Another part that I think is underappreciated is the cinematography. The entire movie looks like a moving photograph. It represents the fact that when you look at one, you remember what happened behind that photograph and the memories begin to start flowing in. It made the movie really feel like it was about the whole family and not just a single person. I also love how they did then ending. It didn't feel depressing or bad at all. For all its trying to be "real", I think at least one of the characters who are getting a divorce should have realistically tried to avoid the divorce and reunite with the partner. Instead, they don't talk to eachother on this level. Even Charlie, who initially seems to consider it only a temporary separation, does not even mention an intention of reunion, sometime in the future. From either side, there's no hint of will of working out the differences and find a compromise, of exploiting the separation for the good of the couple and the family.

Even though it's easy to relate to both the main characters and share their point of view, Nicole is portrayed in a slightly more negative light. She breaks the promise to do without lawyers, which may not have been such a bad thing had she told Charlie she had changed her mind instead of deploying tricks to get an early upper hand. She even goes as far as to mortgage her mom's house to pay the lawyers. That would be understandable under dire circumstances, but not when your husband is begging you to find a consensual agreement and not throw money out of the window, that could instead be saved for the child's future. i myself, as someone who never liked the idea of marriage, see this movie as something that holds great importance, and a wake-up call for the people who are swamped with emotions that couldn't sort themselves out of the mess. of course, me as a young millennial, living in an international big city, has been in an open relationship and believes in polyamory myself, isn't interested in kids and dislikes marriage as a system - it might seem easy for me to get over the ideas, but the challenges presented in the movie are very real, for people who indeed decided to go down the isle: when interests become more intertwined, when there are kids, when the time has been long that it's next to impossible to reverse the roles and expectations established through time in the relationship, the only way out is to break it off, but even that is not easy, and breaking it off by no means is equal to not having feelings anymore. what the lawyers were doing were negotiations, they of course, pointed out the parts that were positive towards their own customer, but as more and more dirty truths (or lies) were spilled out, neither of them was totally innocent without fault, although they both appeared to be genuinely good people. although the ending was really emotional that i was almost crying, and it kinda ended with a positive light, the drama, hurt, betrayal, power and control, the struggle between one's own identity and the role in the relationship and family, those things had left permanent marks that in no way could be lightened by the slightly happy ending. my takeaways on practical marriage and relationship advice would be, first, there's no secret - don't think that you can cheat and hide well, most likely the lies you've told will ultimately come back to you, no matter how innocent your intentions might have been; second, it's very important to be able to maintain one's own identity in a relationship, and compromises especially on the big decisions in life cannot be one sided, and this is particularly important for women who face more pressure from both the society and their intimate partners; third, be as clear as possible about each person's responsibility, the kids can be the most tricky thing, but maybe it would be easier if there were two kids, i'm not very sure. in general, a decision to share a life with someone else is a huge one, don't take it lightly, don't let infatuation be the sole factor in this decision.

The story is basically a husband and a wife going through struggles in their marriage, in the beginning, you wouldn't think they were having problems at all. 
The acting between the husband and the wife towards each other did not feel fake or like you could tell it was written for a movie. It made me feel like I was in real life and it showed the actual reality of a lot of lives that I have never thought of. There is one scene in particular that I think was the one the best acting I've ever seen, and the movie itself was done very well. 
I liked the storyline and how it continued to play out throughout the movie. My favorite part was probably the ending. At first honestly, I thought I hated it, but you think you hate it because you wish the story would have turned out differently. But you know that, again, in reality, the ending is really how it would be in real life. It made me so angry at the end but that's what made it so good. I would usually cry or feel sad for the couple, but instead, I was angry but also content because I knew that's really what life is like. It is definitely a movie for older kids and adults. Aside from the performances, this thing is a hot mess. First, it's not at a "marriage" story at all, but a poorly plotted and executed divorce story. Worse, the film doesn't present a credible motivation for the characters' situation, nor for any of the decisions the characters make. These problems are there from the opening's misdirection where we are treated to how much the protagonists like each other only to shift, with no explanation, into the current setting where they are, inconsistently, alienated. Then, again for no credible reason, Nicole turns to a divorce lawyer and then both characters turn into unidimensional victims of the writer's screed against divorce lawyers. That leads to an unrealistic set piece of everything turning vicious in the courtroom in a way no judge I know would allow. Another set piece follows when Nicole and Charlie, again incredibly, brutally lash out at each other verbally, only to have things end with a predictably bittersweet conclusion where Nicole and Charlie, apparently reconciled to their separation, exchange sad looks. And then there's the rather bizarre back-to-back scenes where Nicole and Charlie both, rather poorly, take on Sondheim numbers. These scenes come out of nowhere, go nowhere, and contribute nothing at all to the story. I suppose, given how badly the rest of this is written, these songs might have been the writer's lazy attempt to use these songs as a commentary on the characters' inner states. But, just like most of the rest of this, they're just another couple of scenes that fail to work. Disappointing.

Marriage Story captures both sides of the story for once, which is kind of rare I would say in the cinematic world. Charlie and Nicole start the story by writing about each other, the things they love about each other when they are in one of the therapist sessions. Nicole declines to share her writings and Charlie was keen on sharing his but Nicole was no longer interested in Charlie or his thoughts. What sounds like a perfect marriage, slowly shows us how the two ends up destroying each other in ways they never thought they could. 
Charlie has always been dependent on his work, his life revolved around his theatre. His choices were based on what he thought would be best, Nicole never had a say and it was getting to a point where she felt she was nothing but worthless as an individual. The writer and the director of the movie have played with emotions, not everything is sad and dull, there is a lot of humor as well. The scene where Nicole wants to serve Charlie with the papers has to be one of the best scenes in the movie, it shows the complete chaos that happens in a family. 
The couple had agreed to solve everything by themselves and make sure that their son does not feel the wrath of the divorce. But when Nicole moves back to LA, she becomes a totally different person, in her terms she's finally free and can make decisions and choices of her own. Henry, their son slowly loses interest in his father as he enjoys his mother's company more. Charlie does not give up on his son easily, he in fact fights for him till the very end. 
You get to experience the true bitter nature of both the characters when they involve the lawyers. Nicole's lawyer Nora is well known to get the best possible deals for her clients, while Charlie struggles to find a lawyer at first, he later finds someone who was very lethargic in nature. Charlie eventually hires Jay after he realizes Nicole is ready to destroy him no matter what. 
A scene where Charlie and Nicole go against each other is probably one of the most emotional scenes of the movie as you get to understand how bad they could taint each other. The movie ends with possibly one of the best sequences in which Henry is reading the notes that Nicole had made in the first scene of the movie, Charlie reads it and eventually bursts into tears and Nicole stands behind him equally emotional. Marriage story is indeed a complete circle.

As a child of divorce, this film is a remarkably realistic and visceral depiction of what divorce is truly like. Throughout the film, the viewer witnesses the good intentions of former spouses be ripped apart by the legal process of divorce and replaced with cruelty, apathy, and unequal conditions. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson gave the best performances of their careers. From screaming matches to the small, intimate moments between the former couple, Driver and Johansson provided so much emotional weight for Noah Baumbach to work with. Laura Dern gave an excellent performance as the cutthroat divorce attorney trying to get her client everything she ever wanted, completely overriding any sentiment Nicole may have still had for Charlie. Despite Charlie's deplorable actions during their marriage, the viewer sympathizes his plight as his world is turned upside down and his son is permanently brought to L.A., a testament to Driver's incredible work with the character. While the apartment meeting scene is by far the most emotionally impactful, there were countless scenes in the film where Charlie and Nicole's pain, anguish, and resignation could be palpably felt. Baumbach did a fantastic job getting the best performances out of Driver and Johansson and his subtle camera shifts during purely conversational scenes helped sell the realism of the film. I was thoroughly overjoyed at the ending as in real life, divorce is not merely bitter arguments and loathing one another (at least in some cases). The love was still present between Nicole and Charlie, it just manifests itself through their mutual love of their son - which is how divorce should be. Overall, Marriage Story is an excellent movie and a testament to how impactful realism in the film industry can be.

I think the first film I remember crying at was Kramer v Kramer; I don't know how old I was, but I remember being in the same room as it when the TV was showing it one Christmas. I don't think I fully understood it - but I know what stayed with me so powerfully was the way I sensed it articulating something of my own fear of my own parents splitting up. Not that I ever had any reason to think that would happen - it didn't. But I remember the fear. 

Many years and 20 years of my own marriage later, Marriage Story doesn't evoke the same fear, but it does evoke both a kind of sadness as to the way it portrays what so many go through, a kind of recognition of the sort of slow escalations that all of us experience in almost any sort of relationship. It's the simple - yet complex - story of a couple's marriage in breakdown ... they start in couple's counselling and ends in divorce, following the negotiation of the details along the way. 

It seems odd to cast the film among the performance industry - he is a theatre director, she an actress; at times that's in danger of tipping the film into the sort of conflicts most of us don't have to deal with, but in the end there's enough truth there to make this feel like an 'everyman' sort of relationship.

The whole film hints occasionally at the heightened realities of musicals - the framing, the tight close-ups and tracking shots following the long speeches of one or the other, maybe even the colour palette at times suggesting the 1950s/60s musicals golden era. When Adam Driver's character, near the film's end, sings a Sondheim song in a bar, that sense is bought closer to the heart; like musicals, the film is unashamed in trying to move us and does so.

Much of this is quite remarkable - Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are outstanding, both of them simultaneously sympathetic and repellant, highlighting the reality that the film doesn't force us to choose one side or the other; or if it does, the way we jump is down to our own biased, not the film's. The film's standout moment, an argument that starts amicably and ends in words that can't be unsaid, is the sort of sequence you feel as if you're privy to someone else's private pain, laundry that should only aired in private hung out for all to see. It's remarkable in performance, direction and writing - and everything else besides. 

The film also mines comedy out of some of the most painful situations; the moment Adam Driver's character is served with divorce papers is almost farce-like in its execution, yet the tonal shift within the scene never jars. Much within the film is funny, because people are funny; there's always a hint of joy, even in the midst of great pain. 

This, I think, is where the hope in the film comes from; given where we are almost certain the film will end right from the first scene, the light touches of humour and the moments of clarity amidst the recriminations, claims and counterclaims point us to the human capacity to be better versions of ourselves even when so much seems to be falling around us. Like the best films, it's never one thing entirely - it's a love story about a divorce, a drama with very good jokes and comedic scenes, a musical with only one song. It's a film about one particular relationship, that allows us to see every relationship (not just marital ones)  in a fresh light.
