Despite its annoyingly vague title, Marriage Story is actually about a divorce. On one level writer-director Noah Baumbach's latest film feels like a divorce procedural. We follow a young attractive couple (Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver) as they agree to keep things simple and not involve lawyers, then involve lawyers, begin a custody battle, and try to navigate all of the emotional and legal complexities of legally dissolving a marriage. On another level, Marriage Story is a showcase of brilliant performances ranging from subtle to ostentatious, comical to moving. I enjoyed Marriage Story far more than I expected though I hesitate to recommend it since very few people (myself included) are able to have a good time by watching people argue and get divorced for over two hours. The divorce gets rocky but the film doesn't so much and if you are in the right mood for a relationship/divorce drama you'll find a decent, somehow, feel good movie.

This is the kind of movie that hangs entirely on its performances. Fortunately, the leads and supporting players all turn in strong performances. Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver have both earned Oscar nominations for their performances as the wife and husband seeking to uncouple themselves while remaining involved with their eight-year-old son and maintaining their careers. Both earn and lose and then earn back your sympathy. Charlie (Driver) is a successful New York theater director whose latest avant-garde production is headed to Broadway. Nicole (Johansson) once starred in a popular Hollywood movie but since meeting and marrying Charlie has committed herself to the stage. A Los Angeles native, Nicole has always wanted to spend more time on the West Coast and now has landed a role in a pilot that will likely become a series. Charlie thinks of them as a New York family and expects Nicole and their son to move back to New York once the pilot is done. When Nicole decides to officially file for divorce the real conflict between them begins.

Baumbach's script does not overtly take sides though it leans toward Charlie, especially toward the end of the film. The explosive climatic argument between Nicole and Charlie gives a chance for both actors to express intense emotions, but it is Driver who gets to let out overwhelming pathos. A court appointed observer—played with welcome awkward comic deadpan by Martha Kelly—is assigned to visit and interview both parents, but we only see the visit Charlie. Charlie does his best to present as an ideal father before the visit falls into dark comedy. In a wonderfully delivered monologue early in the film, Nicole gives us her backstory, both life events and emotional. After this scene the perspective shifts to Charlie and never really shifts back to Nicole. We are as blindsided as Charlie is by claims on money and custody by Nicole's lawyer.

Nora, Nicole's flashy and smoothly confident high-powered lawyer, is played with impressive ease by Laura Dern, who has earned a Best Supporting Actress nomination. We're just as charmed and dazzled by her as Nicole, and just as stung by her as Charlie. Alan Alda delivers some great low-key comedy as Charlie's first divorce lawyer. He's old enough that his hands shake but also old enough to know how bad a divorce can get, and how it will likely end, so, he recommends just starting there. On the complete opposite end of the spectrum is Ray Liotta as Charlie second divorce lawyer, a high powered and extremely expensive pit-bull. He speaks with such speed and ridiculous intensity that he can't help but be funny and believable as a ruthless lawyer. Julie Hagerty is a welcome presence as Nicole's actress mother. She has so much flighty warmth that she secretly helps Charlie find a divorce lawyer.

I'm sure certain viewers that have been through a divorce or even a bad breakup will find something relatable with the characters and situation in Marriage Story. I wouldn't be surprised if other viewers find these characters and their situation unrelatable. Nicole and Charlie, though not wealthy, are in a very upper middle class bracket. They are so accomplished that momentous life changing events like landing a starring role in a TV show and earning an Emmy nomination for directing (Nicole) and winning a MacArthur "genius" grant (Charlie) are just background plot points. Whether you can relate or not, the performances from Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver are of such a rare quality as to keep you invested in their emotional journey.

Before I start this review, I would like to state that I am writing this review the day before the 2020 Oscars. Because of this, I have no idea which of the 8 contestants will win Best Picture. I know that Ford Vs Ferrari doesn't stand a chance, that Jojo Rabbit was probably nominated out of pity, and that Joker is a long shot. Honestly, if it were up to me, none of the nominees would win. Not a single one of my four favorite films of this year were nominated. Dark Waters, Knives Out, Harriet and Avengers: Endgame all missed the boat. However, if I had to choose which one of the actual Oscar nominees would win, I would, without a moment's reflection, choose Marriage Story. The reason this movie is great is because it doesn't actually feel like a movie. Every second of this movie feels like it's actually happening. This is, in part, because of the actors. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson both give perfect performances. Nothing they do feels faked or scripted. There is a scene early on in the movie where Johansson's character has a monologue directed at Laura Dern's character, and it's so well done, it doesn't even feel like a monologue; it feels like a real person, not a character, speaking her mind. Every actor and actress in this movie feels like they are really there, thinking the things they are saying, from the two leads, to the supporting cast (especially Laura Dern), all the way down to seemingly irrelevant featured characters (such as Jazmine Cephas Jones and Martha Kelly's characters). There are several songs performed in the film, and to an outsider, they may seem underperformed or unprofessional. However, that's what makes them work. They aren't being done to wow the audience, they are being done to show that these characters are basically real people, with talents, but also flaws. This is a wonderful film with great performances, great writing and just a general sense of greatness overall.

With "Marriage Story," Writer/director Noah Baumbach goes to a dark place to assess the end of a life shared by two unhappy people, taking over two hours of screentime to assess the difficulties of a specifically challenged marital union. "Marriage Story" is richly detailed, tastefully balanced with some needed comedy, and consistently attentive to the inner lives of the lead characters, who endure all the dehumanization of the divorce process in America. And yet, through the gloom and rising anxiety, Baumbach always preserves the heart of the moment, fleshing out the struggle of legal and emotional separation.

The film stars Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver. Laura Dern, Alan Alda, and Ray Liotta co-star.

Johansson locates surprising areas of honesty for the character, working wonderfully with Baumbach's observant screenplay. Johansson plays an interesting foil, so long in the shadow of her high-profile husband despite being the face of his success in many ways. You can see the pain on her face, but it slowly turns defiant as she discovers a new life and a new (or perhaps rediscovered) sense of self in California. Her performance is Sublime.

Driver has grown into one of the most respected actors of his generation a fearless and magnetic screen presence capable of making you believe everything he's saying no matter the context. He spends much of the film in a bemused haze as their divorce proceedings turn from civil to contentious, unable to understand how things went so sour despite his role in fracturing their relationship. It's the sort of skillful and soulful performance that's expected of him now, and he doesn't disappoint. Their chemistry is undeniable, and their performances sell the emotion of the script with ease.

While Driver and Johansson take up most of the space in the room, there's still enough oxygen for some fun and quirky supporting turns, be it Wallace Shawn's unfathomably horny thespian or Merritt Wever and Julie Hagerty as Nicole's sister and mother, respectively. But it's Dern, decked out in slinky, aggressive power dresses and extreme heels, who effortlessly steals the movie away whenever she enters a scene. She has great fun sparring with Liotta and Alan Alda (as a grandfatherly and mostly inept lawyer who may not be up for the job. "Marriage Story" is all about its performances, and those performances are flawless in every sense of the term.

"Marriage Story" manages to come out on the other side with a sense of calm and understanding, making an extraordinarily difficult viewing experience worth the pain to see how people can keep living even when life is determined to beat all the spirit out of you. The result is a near-perfect piece of transcendent art and one of the true standouts of 2019. 9.5/10

One of the year's best and most balanced movies, Marriage Story succeeds at being both laugh-out-loud funny and heartbreakingly sad. Here, Noah Baumbach shines in his very human and authentic depiction of two genuinely good - if flawed - people trying to navigate their way through an increasingly turbulent divorce. It seems apparent there's an autobiographical element to the movie: Noah began conceiving the film just a few years after his divorce from actress Jennifer Jason Leigh. According to the director himself, his ex wife likes the film a lot. His compassionate and empathic depiction of Nicole is noteworthy. 

Marriage Story feels like it could come straight from Woody Allen's oeuvre. Annie Hall comes closest, I think. But that's probably partly down to switching back and forth between NYC and LA. But watching Noah Baumbach's latest, one is most obviously reminded of Kramer vs Kramer. It's a testament to Marriage Story, then, that after watching it, Kramer vs Kramer feels dated (in fairness, it is forty years old) and Marriage Story feels superior. 

The film vilifies neither Nicole nor Charlie; instead, showing them as victims: victims of an unfair and outdated legal system that cruelly plays both parents off against one another. Insidiously, it strips those fighting for custody of their money, thus creating a desperate situation. The movie illustrates the ensuing escalating tensions through the increasingly unhealthy interaction between the two protagonists, which moves from strained, to quarrelsome, to full-on noxious. But Noah's script is punctuated with humorous and lighthearted moments to balance out the darkest parts.

Both actors are amazing throughout, and so deserving of the accolades they're receiving. But Driver is phenomenal. He elicits real emotion from the viewer, especially in those scenes with his son, which see him try ever so hard to win over his kid's approval. In one stand-out scene, Charlie grabs the microphone and sings Being Alive. It's incredibly engaging, and revealing, too. In another stand-out scene, he finds the notes of his wife, a list of all his greatest qualities, which she had previously refused to share with him. It's beautifully devastating, and Driver communicates the bittersweetness of this simply and powerfully. It's this scene echoes the movie's vibe: hopeful and redemptive even in despairing times.

Yet another movie featuring a filmmaker baring their soul for the audience to celebrate, lament and understand, Noah Baumbach's "Marriage Story" follows in the footsteps of movies like "Lady Bird," "Roma" and the very recent "Honey Boy" in that it's not just an undeniably personal exercise. It's also a supremely well-executed artistic experience on a structural, dramatic, thematic, and technical level. It's rare to have a film operate so meticulously in its characterization process, yet remain so fascinating and emotionally impressive. In many other films, you'd label it a potential issue to have your average scene length be somewhere between 7-10 minutes, and to have most of those scenes involve characters simply talking to one another. But these are very carefully constructed moments of build-up, allowing the audience to breathe these characters in and empathize with every action taken and word spoken, no matter how hurtful or diabolical it may seem on the surface. At the end of the proverbial day, we find we're dealing with nuanced human beings trying desperately to navigate their respective ways through a tragic phase of existence (a kind of death, as the movie so aptly puts it). It's sad, heartwarming, brilliant, and earnest -- an experience I know I'll carry with me for some time.

The story of Charlie and Nicole... One, a highly respected New York Theater director and the other, an L.A. Actress who, in a period of burnout, leaves her L.A. life and moves to New York where she meets, works with, and eventually marries Charlie.

Narration starts the story, where the two characters describe all that they love about each other while we see examples of those words depicted on screen. We then come to find that these "narrations" are actually the written words each has been asked to write about each other as they begin the process of divorce.  A beautifully well crafted and concise way of introducing the characters, establishing their love for each other, and why they married without delaying the main focus of the story... the pains of divorce.

Charlie and Nicole wish to end things as peacefully as possible. However, self-interest (or perhaps a bit of self-preservation) for the lives each wish to live beyond marriage interfere with those goals. The process of divorce, particularly when custody of a child is involved, picks at the wounds that led to the divorce, making it easier to forget what people may have once loved about each other.

Most divorces are a result of paths going in different directions, realizations of things that you may not have seen during the infancy of a relationship. Careers, ambition, feelings of self-worth... they all come into play and are depicted as fuel for the gradual demise of their relationship.

Now, enter the many vultures that surround these two looking to divorce. Divorce attorneys that you almost feel have developed their approaches or styles, perhaps based on some bad divorce they, themselves, had gone through. They do not always seem to have their client's best interests in mind. Their aim to score the win for their client simply fans the fires of pain that may already be encircling the soon to be ex-couple.

Without going further into plot, the biggest success of this film is how each character is a sympathetic character but at the same time, guilty of sins that may have led to current events, signifying there is no ALL Good or ALL bad... no main villain.. but simply two people whose paths intersected at one point, met each other's needs for a time, then ultimately drifted in different directions.

At the center of all of this is their son, who clearly loves both mother and father, who has some connection issues due to distances between father and son, both geographically and emotionally. But through it all, the son serves as catalyst for the rising contentiousness of the interaction between mother and father as they fight for custody.
All told, the story progresses to a moment that showcases some of the best acting I've seen from BOTH actors to date.

I would love to comment on the ending but I hesitate, not because of spoilers, but because I almost feel that the uncertainty of how it ends is part of what gives the ending a satisfying feeling.

Everyone I know who has gotten married or had kids did it before I met them, or stopped hanging out with me almost immediately afterward. Everyone I've ever met who got divorced either did it before I met them, or is someone I stopped hanging out with beforehand. So I don't come to the subject of Marraige Story with a wealth of experience, which means it doesn't exactly scream "relatable content" to me. 

Let me start where it's easiest and everyone seems to agree: The performances. Everyone in Marriage Story is pretty great, none of the characterisations changed my life, but I get it. As a chance to display what these actors are capable of in a mundane setting where all that matters is their performance, yes, absolutely, Marriage Story has buckets of success. 

Outside of this though... I'm not even going to say that it "fails" elsewhere, just that it didn't win me. I like bleak movies, I like movies that make me feel something, even if it's sad. But Marriage Story isn't really that. It poses you the question of whether both Charlie and Nicole are good or bad people, and shows you each from their own and other's perspective. The ending seems to imply that they're good, or at the very least both good and bad (and aren't we all?) but that really doesn't matter very much when we just spent all this time watching both of them be horrible. I know that's life, that's real, that's people, and blah bl-blah bl-blah, but that's little consolation when I've just spent two-plus hours of my life being not at all compelled by a bunch of people being awful. Being awful convincingly, to the actors' respective credits, but in this setting that is not my idea of a good time at the movies.

Adam Driver deserves the nod for this one and "Marriage Story" is another prime example that those who decide who gets an Oscar are not always thinking straight. That's not all what this film accomplishes though ... The lovable Scarlet Johanssen I managed to hate and love as I mentally and vocally reprimanded the couple throughout the duration of the film. "Marriage Story" is an excellent lesson on how not to fall in love with people in the same line of work as you while depicting the griminess of the family legal system as well as the stuffiness of how those types of court battles can leave a person feeling. As I watched the movie I became stressed and belaugared like I was actually in Driver's seat.
 And speaking of Driver's seat, that Invisible Man scene was poetic on so many levels in regards to how father's are treated in patriarchal society. The whole of "Marriage Story" provides great commentary on that as well as marriage as an institution and how the inherent selfishness of humanity ultimately can make such an institution dysfunctional , yet in an odd way by the end of the film, still function on some level.
 As a male viewer, I empathised with Driver's pain and selfishly deluded ways throughout the whole film. "Marriage Story" is as effective as a condom for viewers in my demographic when looking at Driver's characters situation and the lengths he goes just to spend time with his son on the surface, but truly gain a sense of control over what he built and now calls his "life", that he so desperately wants to live and share with those around him as he so eloquently belts out in tenor at a club towards the end of the film.
 "Marriage Story" is a tale of letting go, listening, and honesty and the lengths we as humans will go to keep others around ourselves just to make ourself feel better irregardless of the feelings of the other. "Marriage Story" is what happens when introspection, existentialism, neediness, and slavery walk into a bar and have a loud conversation.

Evaluating this movie fairly is difficult for me, because my experience with divorce was much, much uglier than what was depicted in the film (which was already quite ugly). I never felt particularly emotional as I watched it, possibly because my own past was preventing me from doing so.

That being said, I can not deny that Marriage Story is a true achievement of film making. The courage and self-reflection that Baumbach displayed by telling us the story of his own divorce is remarkable and commendable. Perhaps this is most prevalent in the exquisite screenplay. From the opening scene through the final moments, every line of dialogue feels so cleverly written, yet also completely genuine, as if they are real conversations one might overhear at a coffee shop. The predicaments that the characters find themselves in are heart wrenching, or can become so with a single line that hits the viewer straight in the heart. It tells the story in satisfying ways when needed, and uncomfortable ways when necessary, and these moments transition seamlessly.

The exceptional script would be a waste without an all-star cast, and this movie had talent to spare. The cast is led by Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson in the lead roles. The chemistry (and intentional lack thereof) between the two is among the strongest and most genuine I have ever seen. Driver excels in his role by bringing realism and likability to a character which the script sometimes depicts as selfish and cold. The audience is convinced that this is an authentic, loving father who struggles to adapt when his world turns upside down. Johansson is excellent as the mother; She delivers as the strong, caring mother when with her son, but below the surface, plays the part of a talented artist being trapped and held back, desperate to "find a piece of earth that's hers". 

The ensemble deserves much praise, but the standout is Laura Dern, playing the part of Johannson's divorce attorney. Dern puts on a clinic in "tactics", an acting term referring to the methods characters use to get what they want out of others. The way she manipulates her clients is subtle enough to be mistaken as friendliness, but strong enough to be effective. 

On a technical level, the film's technique is misleadingly simple and plain. The editing, production design, and cinematography don't draw any attention to themselves, but dance together to create a seamless flow to the narrative. Much acclaim goes to Randy Newman's score, which is the lifeblood of several key scenes. 

As mentioned, my biggest disappointment in the film was that i wasn't brought anywhere near to tears, though I wanted to be. I suppose that this can be chalked up to my personal horrid experience with divorce. Even though it didn't strike many chords with me, I appreciate the craftsmanship that went into it and look forward to future works by this director.

'Marriage Story' is written and directed by Noah Baumbach, depicting the divorce of Charlie and Nicole, and showing the inhumane nature of the judiciary system and how it affects their relationship. This film is well written by Baumbach, with the opening scene taking the audience on an unexpected turn, which keeps us on edge for the rest of the film. In his writing and directing Baumbach shows us the hostile nature of the corporate lawyer's world and the toxic effect it has on Charlie and Nicole's relationship, although they are getting divorced, they are by no means on bad terms. Comedy is also excellently weaved into the movie, and not shot or acted in a way that make it over the top. In Charlie and Nicole's argument scene, some lines didn't feel like they suited the character and situation, which in turn lead to overacting, and one character was dull, for comedic effect, however was so overly dull you couldn't buy into it. The cinematography in this film, done by Robbie Ryan and the editing, done by Jennifer Lame, place a lot of focus on shots of only one actor, which does a great job at showing the characters emotions and bringing the intensity to a scene, however, at times it can become a headache for the audience, cutting to and fro from Charlie and Nicole, where a different shot used could still encapture the same intensity and atmosphere to the scene. This film was excellently acted, with Scarlett Johansson (Nicole) and Adam Driver (Charlie) both playing their roles excellently well, with as mentioned before only one moment in the film being slightly overacted. The acting means we never take one side throughout the film as we empathise with both characters which creates a moral dilemma to those audience as to who to agree with and who not, which brilliantly points out that just because two people are divorcing, it isn't necessarily one person's fault. Overall, this film is well worth watching, a really well directed and acted drama with moments of comedy, with the whole film showcasing perfectly the unnecessary wedge being driven between these characters because of how society perceives divorce should happen.

When I say that Marriage Story (dir. Noah Baumbach) made me feel things, I mean it. To be fair, it was 4 am and I wasn't feeling the best mentally when I watched it, but still. As a sucker for just about any rom-com, I was cautious of this film simply because I knew it wasn't going to have a happily-ever-after at the end. In spite of that,  I reccomend this particular movie to anyone who needs a good cry or a good think. I stayed up for at least an hour after finishing the movie, just replaying each of the scenes in my head, examining everything, from the physical take to the stunning dialogue between the characters. I think that's what so excellent about this movie; there aren't any "throw-away" scenes. Every scene in the movie must be there or it wouldn't tell the same story. Adam Driver talked about this phenomenon in an interview he did on a press tour for the release of Marriage Story. He said that every scene in this movie required his utmost focus and care when performing and he couldn't "space out" on any of them or the movie wouldn't be complete. I believe it. This film is rife with metaphor, subtle and not too subtle with the perfect blend of joyous and heart-wrenching moments.

Mad props to Adam Driver and ScarJo for their acting in this film (I personally think it's their best work thus far); their on-screen chemistry sold audiences on their deep love and respect for the other, despite their failing marriage. The very nature of the characters in Marriage Story, Charlie and Nicole (director and actress respectively), lend themselves perfectly to Driver and Johansson because of their careers and the industry they belong to: Hollywood. Their careers end up as the ultimate downfall of their relationship, shedding some light on why so many Hollywood marriages seem to end just about as quickly as they started. If I had to choose a favorite scene from the entire film as a whole without spoiling, it would have to be the opening scenes. The beginning scenes for each character (Charlie and Nicole) parallel each other elegantly, while setting up the story that will soon follow. The voice over is reminiscent of 80's teen dramas and I adore it. The cinematography alone will amaze you not to mention the moods that Baumbach can create with just a lingering shot. The emotions you feel will run the gamut of second-hand embarrassment to straight-up rage, all developed through those elements of film. It's a cinematic masterpiece. 

All I can say after this ENTIRE rant about how much I love this movie is please watch it. I couldn't ask for anything more than to give this amazing film 136 minutes of your life. You won't regret it.

After hearing all of the buzz surrounding this movie and seeing it has so many talented people in the cast from an also talented filmmaker, I knew I had to check this out. Now that I've wiped my tears away, it's time to discuss Marriage Story.  This is the story of a married couple that is going through a divorce, but not wanting to put the stress on their young son, they try to stick together as a family while going through a long legal process to finalize their divorce. 
This film was about as perfect as you can get when it comes to telling this type of story, and it's packed with two of the best performances I have ever seen. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are the best they have ever been and have my votes in the upcoming Oscars for best actor and actress respectively. The only one that can rival Driver is Phoenix which I probably will still ever so slightly side with. Having witness my parents go through a divorce, this movie effected me personally on a deep level. By far the biggest strength of this film is in the screenplay and story, how it's not about the arguing, but how it just destroys a family. Mentally, financially, and in other ways its hard to explain. There were a couple of moments in this film where I was just losing it with tears and again that lies in the performances. They are pitch perfect. THE argument scene was some of the best acting I've ever witnessed in my life. Hearing these characters pour out this heartbreaking dialogue just killed me in a way. The music was so simple and so sad at the same time. I cannot stress enough how much I was impressed by the acting in this movie it's truly mesmerizing. So many extremely long takes of dialogue and the dialogue is not only heartbreaking to listen to, seeing these actors not break character while delivering them is the best part. The ending of this film took me back to the beginning of it and had a big what if scenario in my head. That perhaps was the most heartbreaking part about it, and that goes with the writing and the screenplay. So many people have Netflix today and they better not pass on this one. I really can't find a single flaw with this movie, I honestly can't. This movie took me on an emotional journey I won't soon forget, and Marriage Story ABSOLUTELY gets an A+

An extraordinary, beautiful, depressing, and fulfilling movie by Noah Baumbach. This view into a divorce of a marriage that felt real and felt believable, a divorce not stemming from abuse or absence but from a loss of purpose. The two actors Adam Driver and Scarlett Johnson are absolutely phenomenal and give you a sense that you are going through this time with them. Their relationship is maintained and feels consistent throughout the film although the obvious tearing of the marriage that binds them. Through the film you learn the hardships of the relationship from both sides the mental toll from the marriage and from the split, the moments where both people messed up and where they succeeded. Comedy plays an important role within the movie not only so the movie doesn't drag your emotions too deep but to show how both characters use it as a median to the bad and good. It proves that a sense of humor is human and a path to get through what you may not think you can. The movie does a wonderful job at providing everything you need to see clearly that neither party is the fault of the marriage but the marriage itself. Both Nichole and Charlie are great parents to their kid Henry and share a love for him that is the same love they have for each other, which plays into the story beautifully. The movie starts and ends with the same thing which is positive and very touching. Both Charlie and Nichole are seen pushed to their breaking point, both cracking open and bouncing back within the film making you feel for them as if they are real. Although I do not have any direct view into the world of a divorce it teaches you how horrible it is but how peaceful it can be afterwards. The ending is redeeming and shows how a divorce can better a relationship rather than destroy it. Wonderful movie, absolutely one of Netflix's best so far and justifies itself for many awards.

Marriage Story was definitely the best movie I've watched over the past year. I've never got married, had a kid, or divorced. But after watching this movie, it makes me feel like I have gone through the entire struggling, painful process. There are no dramas throughout the movie, rather, all the stories sounds real, normal and could happen to any married couple that are trying to get divorced.
Time is always cruel and powerful: It can set apart a couple, who used to love each other deeply and exclusively, and now make them fight against each other, (with the help of each's lawyer) , for money, assets and custody of children. All these changes don't take too long — just in few years. 
In the movie, Charlie (the husband) and Nicole ( the wife) had a very intensive fight for over 15 minutes, I was impressed by how angry, unsatisfied, nagging they were. Those negative emotion, that had been suppressed and controlled for years had finally exploded and became devastating. They used the most harsh words to hurt each other. The husband even said he wanted the wife to die. Not surprisingly, they finally divorced. But I was very sad about the ending of the story. They could have had a happy family, watching their kid grow up together, but they terminated it because of disputes on chores and small things in lives. Had they communicated their negative emotion timely and thoroughly whenever the issue arose, and weren't leave it accumulated, a divorce can be avoided.
But it was too late to say this. Nicole had already started her new life in LA with her boyfriend. A divorce was already a divorce, nothing can get back. 
What I've learned is: life won't give you a chance to regret, and move backward. A broken heart will never be healed completely. You have to move on to embrace your new life, And let the past be an unforgettable memory. 
I highly recommend this movie, because it gives you a good chance to rethink about marriage, life and divorce.

Review:
‘Marriage Story' is a comedy-drama film directed by Noah Baumbach.
This movie was in contention of being my favorite of the year. ‘Joker' just slightly edged it's way to be my number one.
The film follows a married couple (Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver) going through a coast-to-coast divorce.
Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson hit it out of the park with these incredible performances. They're great throughout the whole film, but there is a certain scene in this movie that everybody will talk about and it floored me. They way they act towards each other, they have great chemistry. Laura Dern also did a great job, playing a slimeball lawyer who keeps taking Johansson's character into things she doesn't want to do.
The real hero of this story however is Noah Baumbach, who also wrote the film and deserves all the praise. He is a true master in writing and directing. He makes all of it seem effortless, with unprecedented results. He could truly be one of the last true story tellers working today.
Overall, the movie to me is basically flawless. It makes you laugh; it makes you cry; it even makes you feel things you can't identify. It's a heartbreaking story about how two people can love each other, but still know they aren't good for each other.
5/5

An updated "Kramer vs. Kramer" (1979), Noah Baumbach's divorce drama "Marriage Story" is already engendering backlash for being a drama about well-off white people bickering. It's more than that. It's a beautifully written and observed piece about what brings us together, and what remains when our bond grows brittle and shatters. Baumbach's script is a revelation (and a likely Oscar nominee or winner), but so are the powerful performances by Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver, both at their best, whose characters we alternately root for or despise as if we are breaking up with each of them ourselves. That fight scene! That show tune scene! Laura Dern and Alan Alda make the most of well-crafted parts as lawyers, one a shark (Dern, uncomfortably close to her work on "Big Little Lies" from 2017-present) and one a confoundingly laissez-faire pushover (Alda) ... or is that wisdom? Do not sleep on the work by Julie Hagerty as a mom who refuses to choose sides and Ray Liotta as a counselor who swims in the same school as Dern's character. If the mounting backlash to the film doesn't damage it, it could sweep the major categories at the Oscars in February. P.S. If you missed Baumbach's "The Meyerowitz Stories" (2017), as I did until recently ... it's even better.

As the name suggests, "Story of a Marriage" deals with the breakup of a relationship of an established couple and a child, the long brush outlines the reasons for the breakup but focuses on showing the consequences of a breakup, his drama sometimes escalating. too much, and its hatred and ramifications are strange in the very sense established and created by the film, but as already had, its conclusion is beautiful and poetic, a charming third act that concludes and circumvents its errors very effectively.

The direction is simple but has an exquisite use of the camera and framing, always highlighting the distance of the couple and opening up to monologues and views, which are always filled with great performances, the whole cast is fine, Adam Drive and Scarlett Johansson has phenomenal chemistry, and both actors are great in their roles.

"Marriage Story" is a good movie, it deserves and will take some Oscar nominations, but again, it's a very contextual movie that needs a previous viewer experience, those who don't have that traumatic experience, will see the qualities of the movie but will not feel all your sentimentality. It reminds us what it is to be cast in the most negative light - to be seen at our worst- and then reminds us of the importance of love and why love, even waning love, is never futile. Experiences, even negative ones, can teach us lessons about who we are and what is important.

I'm a little surprised by this one.  With all the praise flying around about this movie, I thought it would be better.  Not that it's bad; it's definitely a good movie.  I just expected to be blown away, and was not.  It's just not as powerful or as emotionally devastating as I was led to believe.  It's a poignant, true-to-life drama about two utterly believable (if not so sympathetic) characters that more than a fair share of the population will relate to, whether they are willing to admit it or not.  But it did not affect me in the way some other movies with similar subjects have.  A more apt title for this film would have been "Divorce Story" – it's more about the grueling legal process of a contentious divorce and custody battle than the marriage that led up to it.  It's often uncomfortable to watch; the emotion it evokes is anger more than empathy, watching what that process can do to two otherwise reasonable people that care about each other.  The movie does a good job of showing both characters' viewpoints and bringing you along on their journeys, so you feel like you are going through it all with them.  Both characters are flawed and are hard to root for, but that was the intent – marriage is messy and divorce is a goddamn disaster, even for the best of people.  The film just didn't make me care much for either of them until I was pretty deep into it, when all the tension that has been subtly building over the course of the film comes to a head in one explosive scene (if you've seen the film, you know the scene I mean… it's a gutter, and Driver and Johannson could not have been more convincing together).  This film is what you call an "actor's film" – it's focused on character and heavy on dialogue, (plus some whopper monologues), to the point where it often feels like you're watching a play.  It has all the makings of an Oscar winner:  a celebrated auteur writer/director in Noah Baumbach, two stellar actors at the top of their game, and a resonant drama at its core.  It's the kind of movie that Academy voters eat up with a spoon and it's a shoo-in for Best Picture, Best Actor/Actress, and Best Director nominations, plus a writing nomination thrown in for good measure. The only question is whether or not its affiliation with Netflix will kill its chances for the big prize come Oscar night.

Marriage Story is so powerful and real in its presentation of a divorce that I almost hated it. I am not a big fan of movies that focus on couples bickering a lot, because I generally seek escapism in film, and don’t want to spend my time watching relationships fall apart. However, I simply couldn’t bring myself to hate this movie because it is perfectly acted, has moments of levity among the sorrow, and feels so genuinely heart-wrenching in how far the relationship has fallen. We can see, as their divorce draws closer, they still retain some faint echoes of the love they once felt for each other. I’m fairly confident that Noah Baumbach must have written this based on personal experience, because it is too authentic to be entirely fabricated out of nowhere (and at times the film seems to cast the wife in a more negative light than the husband.) Scarlett Johansson brings her A game here, and it’s hard to deny her talent. Yet it’s Adam Driver who impressed me even more, because he delivers a truly astounding performance loaded with nuance and emotion. There are some scenes in Marriage Story where so much is communicated by Driver with only looks and body language. You can feel the hurt hiding behind a casual conversation, and when it explodes, the vitriol is truly shocking. There is no denying that, for those who like a realistic relationship drama, Marriage Story might be one of the best films in years. However, while I tip my hat to the quality of the film (and commend them for making the movie that Blue Valentine wishes it could have been) it’s still a style of story that is a tough sell for me. I appreciate that it exists, but I never want to watch it again.

If there was ever a movie to make me never want to get married because of the ugliness of divorce this is it. Marriage Story should really have been titled Divorce Story because we follow couple Charlie (Adam Driver) a theater director, and Nicole (Scarlett Johansson) an actress, who are getting a divorce. They have agreed to not use lawyers and to settle this just between themselves. They have a son named Henry (Azhy Robertson), so of course that complicates matters. Nicole lands a pilot in Los Angeles, so she decides to take Henry and move in with her mom temporarily. While in Los Angeles someone tell she should get a lawyer for the divorce, so that she doesn't get screwed over. Nicole hires Nora Fanshaw (Laura Dern) who specializes in divorce. Suddenly, Charlie is thrown into this and has to scramble to get his own lawyer. The rest of the film portrays the hard decisions of divorce and how two people that still may love each other slowly start to unravel and change. It's some pretty deep stuff here and I would say it's a great movie, but not a film I'd watch more than once because of the somewhat depressing subject matter. The two leads performances in Driver and Johansson are great here. They have some scenes together that are so realistic that it's hard to believe this was all scripted. You feel for both of their sides and I personally couldn't side with either or during it all. It's a heartbreaking film and I have my own opinions of the ending and what could be happening here, but I won't spoil it all. This is an incredibly well acted movie, but also not exactly pick me up kind of film. Definitely, recommend checking it out though on Netflix!

I kept waiting for Charlie and Nicole to get caught in a moment of lust at least once.  I was left dissatisfied by the lack of the intimacy despite the chemistry that was built up between them.   The movie is called "Marriage Story," but it's nothing of the sort.  It starts off with Charlie and Nicole reading over a list of things they love about each other only to find out it was an assignment from their mediator.  This is not a story of Marriage.  It's a story of divorce, heartbreak, and grief.   I don't know about you, but I have enough of that in my life.  Movies are supposed to be an escape from reality, not a reminder. MARRIAGE STORY by Armen Pandola

Netflix's Marriage Story, written and directed by Noah Baumback (The Meyerowitz Stories) and starring Scarlett Johansson as Nicole and Adam Driver as Charlie, tells the story of the divorce of two young artists at the beginning of their careers. She is a young actress known for a topless scene in her last movie (this is according to the people in this movie) and he is an avant garde theater director and head of his own company in New York City.  When they meet by chance, they fall in love and she moves to NYC where she becomes the 'draw' for his theater company. Eventually, they have a son. At the beginning of the movie, they are getting a divorce after 10 years and are seeing a mediator in the hope of having a  friendly divorce.

Is it a spoiler to tell you that a friendly divorce is rarer than a vegetarian meal at Mar-a-Lago? I knew a couple who mediated their divorce and everything was going well until they got to the jazz album collection (this was back in the day) which they were to split evenly. He objected - she didn't know Dizzy Gillespie from Dizzy Dean when I met her. She countered - yes, he introduced me to jazz but I was the one who actually bought and cared for our collection of over a 1000 albums - if it were up to him, he'd still be using his albums as coasters at the drunken parties he and his friends threw every week. And so much for mediation.

The upshot of Marriage Story is that good people get divorced and often do terrible things, things they'd never dream of doing except for the divorce. And that's what happens to Nicole and Charlie. The contested divorce legal process is unfair and incredibly expensive. Laura Dern is Nicole's lawyer and she explains to Nicole that she cannot admit to any wrong-doing or even any flaws since our world treats women/wives/mothers so differently than men/husbands/fathers. Women/wives/mothers must be like Mary, mother of Christ and a virgin to boot. Men are like Joseph - who is absent when the going gets tough and isn't even the actual father who is away somewhere doing whatever it is that gods do.

The other side is represented by Ray Liotta who tells Charlie that he had better get ready to be demonized and pay legal bills and costs that would make a lottery winner cringe. At first, Charlie is represented by a nice lawyer played by Alan Alda who tells him, "We have to prepare to go to court hoping we don't go to court." When Charlie sees that Dern is crushing Alda at a meeting, he switches to Liotta who can talk faster and be meaner than anybody else.

Along the way, there's a custody dispute. At the very beginning of the divorce, Nicole goes to LA to do a TV pilot (her first acting job outside her husband's company in a decade)  and takes their son with her. The expectation is that she will return to NYC when the pilot is completed but then - she doesn't. Her family is in LA where she grew up and made a career as an actress. The money is exponentially better than doing theatre work. So, Charlie can only see his son by traveling cross country on weekends.  As is usual in divorces where there are children,  the child becomes the center of the divorce with each side claiming that it knows best for the child. Of course, the divorce is devastating to children, but that is a different movie and Baumbach concentrates on the adults.

It gets complicated quickly. The heart of the story is told in long takes where both Johansson and Driver communicate their rage at what is happening to them and the man/woman they loved. These longs takes show both Johansson and Driver's acting chops - each of them is able to build a scene to the point where real emotions are on display. The hateful argument  they have at the end of the divorce process is contrasted with the tender affection for both their partner's qualities and deficiencies that they talk about at the beginning of the process. In fact, it is probably true to say that if you can find a person who loves not only your wit and charm, but your surliness and bad habits, then you should chase him/her until you catch him/her because that is the person who loves you.

Two songs from Sondheim's Company are sung - "You Could Drive a Person Crazy" by Nicole and her actress mother and actress sister, played beautifully by the under-appreciated Julie Haggerty and Merritt Wever, and "Being Alive" from the same musical sung by Driver. Each song speaks to what their characters are feeling about each other. Strangely, in Company, there is even a more appropriate song they could have sung - The Little Things You Do Together:


It's the little things you share together,
Swear together,
Wear together,
That make perfect relationships.
The concerts you enjoy together,
Neighbors you annoy together,
Children you destroy together,
That keep marriage intact.

It's not talk of God and the decade ahead that
Allows you to get through the worst.
It's "I do" and "you don't" and "nobody said that"
And "who brought the subject up first?"
It's the little things,
The little things, the little things, the little things.

There is so much to recommend this movie that I hesitate to mention a few missteps. While money is mentioned, often, it isn't really talked about in substance. The fact is that many people never recover, financially, from a divorce. This is partially solved in the movie by a gift from the gods that drops in their lap during the divorce. A bigger problem is that Baumbach wants it both ways - the great angry scenes where people say things to each other that they don't mean, but once said can never be unsaid, and the happy ending. One of the best angry arguments that Nicole and Charlie have is negated by their embrace at its end. The fact is that arguments drive people further apart and don't end in an embrace but, usually, a slammed door.  There are some maudlin scenes whose purpose is to show that they have moved on with their lives and are doing fine, and still think of each other with love and affection. And a divorce that ends that way is rarer than a 2-for-1 meal at Mar-a-Lago.

Wow. What a great story about relationships and the beginnings and endings of them. Marriage Story is a flawless, heartbreaking story led by two of some of the best performances of the year. Adam Driver is phenomenal. Most people know him from the new Star Wars Trilogy but people should really see some of his other films. He usually does a great job but in this film, he is 100% dedicated to the role. They are certain scenes in the film where it doesn't feel like he is acting. It feels as if he is actually this character and going through all of these troubles. He puts so much emotion into his performance that it is heartbreaking yet mesmerizing. Scarlett Johansson gives yet again another fantastic performance. While her performance isn't as mesmerizing as Driver's performance, it's still perfect. She also conveys a huge amount of emotion with her role but adds a slightly more comedic and relaxed atmosphere to Driver's serious and hardworking atmosphere. Both actors play off each other perfectly, even in scenes where their characters are fighting with each other. Every other performance in the film is pretty great, especially from Laura Dern. The script for Marriage Story is fantastic. It compliments the performances and feels very natural. It knows how much the characters need to say to get a point across or when to restrict them. The music and cinematography are great. The music is done by Randy Newman (Toy Story) and fits the depressing tone the film is going for. The film makes the good choice of not using music during certain dramatic scenes which helps make those scenes more emotional. The cinematography isn't groundbreaking by any means but there are a lot of beautiful shots. Towards the beginning of the movie, there is a 5 minute uncut shot of Scarlett Johansson talking about why she stopped being in love with Adam Driver's character and it's great. There is one sequence in the film that is perfectly shot, acted, and scripted and it's the argument scene. I felt sad and a smidge emotional for the characters throughout the film but this one scene made me feel a whole lot. It's one of the best scenes in cinema this year. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson completely disappear in this scene. It doesn't feel like acting. It feels like the filmmakers just filmed real people breaking apart. The emotion displayed in this one scene is off the charts. It cemented for me that Adam Driver is a masterclass actor that people should pay more attention to besides being known as "the guy from Star Wars". The rest of the film has its emotional moments but they don't top that scene. The film's plot is pretty straightforward but the way the characters interact makes the film feel unpredictable. Noah Baumbach used his direction to make a straightforward story feel unique. I'm going to start paying more attention to Baumbach from here on out. Overall, Marriage Story is a fantastic film about relationships and divorce with some of the best performances of the year, an outstanding screenplay, unique direction, and some great cinematography and music.

A well honed and admirable capturing of a marriage between two artists navigating the tumults of the personal and professional in the 21st century. Crisply written, with an emotionally bristling performance from Driver, the film delivers us inside their relationship in Baumbach-ian form. Scenes shine where actors are given the time and language to build and gather momentum -- Driver and Scarjo; Dern and Liotta. While the middle clunks along with back and forths to and from NY-LA and Driver's incessant search for a lawyer, the authentic performances and attention to detail carry the film. While the writer/director lived his research, the personal doesn't get in the way of cinematic storytelling, instead, fuels it. Much of the magic here comes through nuance -- a juxtaposition of frames, a silent act of generosity, even a look. With dashes of much needed comedy, Marriage Story avoids the trappings of melodrama and sentimentality and is the kind of small intimate story we rarely get these days -- too often passed over by producers and audiences alike. Without a "happy ending" or a winning party, much less a clear battle between good and evil, instead, Marriage Story is a cross section of 2 lives, and a worthy contribution to the cinematic relationship canon.

At times this movie was painful to watch; the description of the legal process tracked a little too close to home. From your (ex) partner telling you different things than they're telling their attorney, to the attorneys taking extreme positions to maximize billing through the protracted meeting of the minds, to the emotional cost, the financial cost...the portrayal of the system is accurate, insightful, and visceral. 

Almost everyone becomes rewarded for selfishness. Attorneys get to bill more at ungodly rates for very basic work, and the parties are rewarded for only thinking of themselves in a zero sum game. Who loses? Well, everyone...but that loss becomes part of the process as well. The mental anguish becomes a sacrifice for the attorney fees/increased time, couples look back with bitterness, and children suffer from the cross fire. 

I'm not sure if it was therapeutic to see it's not just me, and to have something I could relate to so deeply...but this should definitely be seen as a very accurate warning sign for couples separating. I suspect that it was exorcism of a few demons for the writer/director as well.

Marriage Story Review:

Marriage Story is written and directed by Noah Baumbach and stars Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver as a couple going through a divorce.  This divorce pushes them to their limits and changes them, but while this is affecting them they're also trying to provide a happy environment for their son.  In about August, this became my most anticipated film of the year.  I just love Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver proved to be great with his Oscar nomination for BlacKkKlansman.  Also I discovered Noah Baumbach last year with his film While We're Young which I think is very underrated.  He's had a few Oscar nominations and is just a great screenwriter and director.  Before Marriage Story my favorite of his was the slice of life Frances Ha.  This film affected me on so many levels emotionally.  I don't know how one could possibly watch this without shedding at least one tear.  It's so incredibly real and it's just amazing how it all played out.  Scarlett Johansson has her best performance once again.  I feel like every time she's in a film she just gets better and better. Scarlett Johansson has her best performance once again.  I feel like every time she's in a film she just gets better and better.  The hardest part about this film is that it shows both sides and you can switch back and forth between who you like more and who you like less.  But also you don't want them to split up.  Noah Baumbach did great with this because it's a frustrating film.  It engages you into the characters and story so much that you start to feel so much anger and frustration and happiness and comedy.  The tone has literally everything and blends it great.  Back to the comedy, this film has some pretty funny moments that helped with the depressing tone.  Marriage Story just made me depressed, especially the very end, and it still lingered after I watched it.  The very end just crushed me but it was also the best scene in the whole film.  Just everything blends so nicely in this.  Randy Newman's score is one of my favorites of the year.  It's so joyful and sad at the same time.  Listening to it before seeing the film I was confused how it would work with the story, because there are times where it sounded just so animated.  It just worked perfectly.  I also liked the aspect ratio choice of 1.66:1 because it felt more like a home movie.  To me 1.33:1 and 1.66:1 work nice for a home movie feel.  Everything was just so realistic in this and I didn't want it to end.  This has become my fourth favorite film of the year so far.  Also it's one of those films where I don't want to rewatch it too much so it surprises me every time with how great it is.  I do that with my favorite films.  Marriage Story is a film that should be recognized as one of the best of the decade.  It demonstrates peak storytelling, superb acting, and shows that Noah Baumbach is one of the best directors out there.  I really think it would be cool if it won best picture, screenplay, and acting.  There are so many words I have for this and I want to talk about it for a while.  I think I'll leave it like this so you can experience it for yourself.  Marriage Story is another perfect movie of the year.

My Grade: A+

Noah Baumbach's indie divorce drama Marriage Story (2019) is a heartfelt retrospective on his failed marriage to Jennifer Jason Leigh. As awful as the divorce proceedings get, Marriage Story succeeds in entertaining and resonating as it's not a vitriolic or hateful movie. Baumbach's writing is reflective and fair to my perspective. He establishes how genuine and loving their relationship started with touching letters of positive aspects, then delves into what made with marriage fizzle out, and finally assigns blame to both parties. Noah Baumbach's Marriage Story is a resounding triumph of goodwill and heartbreak through an empathetic lens. He understands the pain and perspective of each of his leads making for realistic and honest writing. Noah has crafted a fine art film about marriage, divorce, and love in one of 2019's best movies: Marriage Story.

Scarlett Johansson is poignant as Nicole Barber, who felt held back and unappreciated in her marriage. Johansson gives her leading lady a striking voice of adoring wife, decent mother, talented actress, fun partner, vindictive divorcee, and resentful spouse. It's a complicated role that ensures you empathize with her disconnected experience and sympathize with her hurt pride and concerned persona. I appreciate her hurt eyes and nuanced faces. She says so much with subtle changes in expression and tearful monologues. She is intimate in this role like I have not seen Scarlett since Sofia Coppola's Lost in Translation. Considering Scarlett's best acting is in Lost in Translation, Her, and now Marriage Story, she should continue to delve into the emotionally devastating world of divorce. At least, I hope Scarlett Johansson acts in more serious dramas like Marriage Story!

Adam Driver delivers a masterful dramatic leading man role in Marriage Story as Charlie Barber. He is fascinating as a doting father, dedicated director, passionate artist, fun guy, and neglectful husband. Driver's finest acting is here in Marriage Story. I loved him in Silence and BlacKKKlansman, but Marriage Story is nuanced like few actors could ever hope to achieve. His shocked expressions are very understated. The way he puts his hand to his mouth to cover up his pain or his sudden outrage at his spouse displeasure is inspired. His quiet depiction of suffering is as riveting as his burst of frustration when he and Scarlett scream at each other in a phenomenally entertaining scene. He sings a sullen song in a depressing scene, but his refined performance equals Scarlett's all encompassing role. Adam Driver is a character actor with range as exemplified in Marriage Story with good humor, kind affection, gentle manner, dejected anguish, indignant disgust, rage filled fury, and defeated nonchalance. He displays Charlie's heart openly for all the world to feel.

I adore Laura Dern's viper divorce lawyer Nora Fanshaw going for everything. Dern demonstrates a phenomenal irreverence for the pain of others as a cold hearted woman beaten down by divorce herself, gunning for every last cent on behalf of her client. Dern is delightful to watch as she destroys a man's life with a determined glee. Her ruthless attitude would work for a mafia boss as well as it does in Marriage Story as an L.A. divorce lawyer.
Likewise, Ray Liotta brings cunning and sharpness to his brutally honest divorce lawyer Jay Marotta. He is the ideal verbal and legal duellist for Laura Dern. Their courtroom banter is like watching fire spit upon fire in hellish combat. It's one of Marriage Story's best sequences. I love Ray Liotta in Marriage Story as you are on edge in eager anticipation of his next argument.

On the other hand, Alan Alda gives a funny supporting role as a fatalist divorce lawyer already counting Charlie out named Bert Spitz. His dry wit is amusing, but his hopeless attitude is the saddest aspect to his intriguing character. Wallace Shawn even has a funny cameo in Marriage Story as the inappropriate veteran actor. I liked Azhy Robertson's performance as the young boy Henry Barber, who goes from indecisive to spoiled and back to affectionate all within a single scene. Julie Hagerty is hilarious as Scarlett's valley girl mom Sandra. I dearly enjoyed Merritt Wever's cameo as Scarlett's sister Cassie. Her anxious dread at having to serve Charlie is too relatable and hilarious.

Alongside Baumbach's empathetic lens as writer, his direction for Marriage Story is fantastic. He captivates you by telling each side of the story openly and in intimate spaces. Noah Baumbach's indie direction is simple and sleek so as to allow his cast to perform as if on a stage. His open and free style is earnest with stark images of hatred, loathing, disappointment, shock, betrayal, and affection alike. Noah Baumbach's indie direction feels more like you are watching a documentary of this divorce rather than a film. Marriage Story is akin to awkwardly sitting in a room with divorce proceedings occurring.

Jennifer Lame's editing is very pretty and smooth as she seamlessly shifts scenes from Charlie to Nicole with effortless cuts that keep you engaged. Marriage Story is nearly two and a half hours, yet it only feels like one due to Lame's gentle hand.

All of cinematographer Robbie Ryan's close-up shots of hurt faces and crying eyes made my own eyes cry tears. Marriage Story is deeply affecting and wholly engrossing as you absorb all the adoration and resentment of these characters. Many medium shots reveal all the awkward body language and unspoken feelings in impressively executed long takes. Baumbach and Ryan fasten your focus purely on the emotional distress caused in each scene with unwavering camerawork.

Randy Newman's score is beautiful with soft strings and melancholic classical to underline the sorrowful tone of Marriage Story. His music is nice to hear and never oversteps his boundaries to distract from the story, performances, or direction. Newman composes subtle melodies that chime in only when necessary like a warm blanket appearing when you need it.

Finally, I'm sure Marriage Story will prevail at The Oscars, deservedly so, for its powerful performances, personal writing, and grounded direction. Noah Baumbach opens his heart to ensure that Scarlett Johansson and Adam Driver can depict complex, flawed characters that feel like real people. Marriage Story is sure to become a classic piece of Americana.

Noah Baumbach's "Marriage Story" is a witty, tender and heartbreaking divorce drama that is propelled by a pair of powerful performances from Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson. With his latest feature, writer/director Noah Baumbach has crafted a powerful portrait of a couple going through a painstaking divorce. In spite of the serious subject matter, the film is by turns funny and heartbreaking. Baumbach's screenplay is excellent and captures the process of divorce in a piercingly honest and authentic way. Filled with compelling characters, witty dialogue and realistic situations, the script elevates the movie to another level. Aside from excelling behind the camera, Baumbach draws excellent performances from his cast. Adam Driver and Scarlett Johansson are incredible in the lead roles, creating a fractured relationship that is utterly believable. Driver delivers his finest performance to date as Charlie. Intense, charismatic and emotionally resonant, he proves that he is one of the finest actors working today. Johansson, on the other hand, is award-worthy in one of her first dramatic roles. With emotional expressions, she captures the frustrations of a women that is dissatisfied with her relationship. Both actors carry the film firmly on their shoulders. Although "Marriage Story" offers heartwarming entertainment, ultimately it is not a film without flaws. If I had a minor issue with the movie, it would be the lengthy running-time. At over two hours, it is slightly long and could have been tighter in length. Nevertheless, fans of dramas will definitely enjoy "Marriage Story" and so will anyone that has ever gone through a divorce. It offers a heartfelt portrayal of a divorce that is sure to be remembered come awards season.

Something of a modern-day Kramer vs. Kramer, but with all the personality and identity required to make it it's own thing, Marriage Story's power and poignancy rests largely on the acting talents of its 2 leads, who give arguably their best screen performances to date. Both are fraught and frequently on edge, but they both do a lot to convince you that the separating couple once had immense love and respect for one another, especially with the opening sequences which is brought back beautifully towards the end. It tells the story from both sides, and shows just how ugly a divorce can become, especially when a child is caught in the middle and doesn't fully understand what is happening. It also addresses the problems that both men and women, especially the former, face in obtaining custody, and the struggle a parent will go through for that right. Its informed by reality and keenly observes the mundane moments of court battles with wit and humour and the more contentious moments with sympathy and understanding. Noah Baumbach is a forced to be reckoned with in the movie world, with this and The Meyerowitz Stories demonstrating his prowess both behind the camera and the typewriter. Marriage Story shows how a separation can be both devastating and revelatory, how it can tear 2 people apart, but allow you to see things in the other person that you didn't before. It's mostly a showcase for its 2 actors, but everything it brings to the table make it a film worth seeing.

Until the Golden Globe nominations were announced I hadn’t even heard of Marriage Story. But, there it was: Best Actor Drama, Best Actress Drama, Best Supporting Actress, Best Drama, Best Screenplay and Best Original Score. Good grief! I haven’t exactly been hiding under a rock when it comes to movies! Fully chagrined I clicked on Netflix and settled in, fully expecting to be overwhelmingly impressed. I wasn’t but that’s not an indictment by any means. The film was really good just not over the top Bravo! The storyline is actually quite common, one many of us have lived: marriage adrift, divorce, child custody, division of property….“let’s keep this fair and civil, do what’s best for the kids.” If we’re lucky, amicable works. If not, our lives grind to a brutal, angry halt while attorneys screw everything up and money rolls downhill so their kids can relax about college tuition while our kids start applying for financial aid. Watching Marriage Story is like sitting through 136 minutes of bad lawyer jokes springing to life. The horror. Charlie (Adam Driver), a director of cutting-edge, avant-garde theater, positioned to take his latest work to Broadway, is married to Nicole (Scarlett Johansson), an actress fading from NYC stage renown but still popular in Hollywood. The couple have grown apart, recognizing, despite deeply caring for each other, the point of departure has arrived. Divorce is discussed. Their young son Henry (Azhy Robertson) is the beloved prize and both parents start out determined his interests be top priority. Then a wrinkle emerges. Nicole accepts a career revival offer to film a pilot in Los Angeles. She takes Henry with her to California, moving in with her Charlie-adoring mom (Julie Hagerty). On one of Charlie’s frequent coast-to-coast trips to spend time with his family, Nicole bullies her reluctant Charlie-adoring sister Cassie (Merritt Wever) to serve him with divorce papers, smuggled under a pecan pie, then hires Nora Fanshaw (Larua Dern) as her attorney, a bulldog lawyer who approaches divorce in a “there will be blood” crusade. Nora relishes in threatening Charlie with loss of all earthly possessions and any hint of custody. Charlie is forced to retaliate. Enter divorce Death Star Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta). At this point we strap in for a gut-wrenching saga of two legal vipers squaring off to pound the other side to pulp, not caring a whit that “sides” are flesh and blood people, parents at a starting line of good intentions. Charlie and Nicole recoil, shatterIng under scathing legal posturing and purposeful courtroom annihilation. Even Henry is a won/lost tally at times, the wretched center flag of a parental tug-of-war, Charlie pulling one arm, Nicole the other. Everyone is expendable as collateral damage, Charlie literally bleeding out on his rented California apartment floor in one grueling black humor kitchen scene. Lord, have mercy. What materializes below the waves of the legal hurricane are two decent people, Charlie and Nicole, trying—mostly futilely—but trying nevertheless to resist succumbing to emotional cruelty. Predictably, tirades of fury and fear simmer, seethe and eventually explode. Human combustion. As the vitriol flies, you regret on their behalf what they’re unleashing— hateful, damning words that can never be taken back, that will echo forever no matter how hard they may wish differently. We’ve all been there. The film taps our jagged relational regrets, remorse and repentance, making “I’m sorry,” a communal mantra of misery. You want to jump up and shout at the screen, “Stop! Don’t say it! Just stop, please.” Adam Driver is not a favorite of mine, he’s so Keanu Reeves with a distinctive monotone delivery, but he did stretch his dramatic persona for this role, perhaps his best performance to date. Petty question #1: how did 6’2” Driver gets cast with 5’3” Scarlett Johansson? He towered over her. Maybe it was to serve as a visual metaphor for their professional director/actress relationship. Truthfully, Johansson failed to win me over, I never warmed up to Nicole. I was rooting for Charlie, put off by Nicole and annoyed by Henry. Petty question #2: isn’t Henry way too big for a car seat? Cassie, Nicole’s witty sister, was my favorite of all the characters. For the record I am a total Merritt Wever groupie, my enthusiasm for her in Nurse Jackie morphed to sheer hero worship in Netflix’s Godless, the last scene I can watch over and over and over until I’m the last person awake in the household. There were enough funny exchanges in this film, comedy infusion, that thankfully lightened the heavy laden angst. While the attorneys square off, family members rise and fall in their humanness. It’s like taking a selfie of our worst selves against a background of laughter, kindness, and thoughtfulness. If the goal is to showcase the competing dualism of the human spirit then Marriage Story charges ahead of the 2019 drama pack. MARRIAGE STORY-2019(R)-Nov. 29. By:Clem The Movie Guy. Thanksgiving weekend, I got a chance to see an exclusive screening of Marriage Story, the new film from acclaimed writer & director Noah Baumbach. Loosely inspired by Baumbach’s own personal experience & further informed by conversations with friends & lawyers, Marriage Story is an intensely compelling & a realistic look at a married couple going through the turmoil of divorce. Once madly in love with each other, Charlie (Adam Driver), a gifted New York theatre director & Nicole (Scarlett Johansson), a former teen Hollywood film actress who now only performs in his off-Broadway plays, are having trouble with their marriage. Charlie is intensely & somewhat selfishly focused on his work. Nicole has grown tired of living in the shadow of Charlie’s aspirations as Charlie grows increasingly obvious to Nicole’s hopes & dreams. After receiving the offer of a starring role in a television pilot & with the divorce in early stages, Nicole leaves the theatre company & moves to Los Angeles with their young son, Henry (Azhy Robertson) while Charlie remains in New York to see to the process of his play going to Broadway. Later, arriving for a visit in Los Angeles to see Nicole & Henry, Charlie is stunned when he is served with divorce papers, believing that he & Nicole had agreed on an amicably split & to forego using lawyers. Nicole has been persuaded to hire a powerful attorney, Nora Fanshaw (Laura Dern), which inevitably forces Charlie to follow suit. Initially he hires Bert Spitz (Alan Alda), a retired family lawyer who favors a more civil & conciliatory approach but as the contention grows, Charlie must resort to a more aggressive lawyer, Jay Marotta (Ray Liotta). Marriage Story shows not only the difficulties of compromise & self-sacrifice in marriage, further complicated by trying to protect any children involved, but the legal system at its worst with ruthless lawyers manipulating their vulnerable clients. The performances from Adam Driver & Scarlett Johansson were raw & captivating. I believe that Adam Driver gives one of the best performances of his career. I won’t be surprised to see Marriage Story receiving major award consideration for Best Picture, Noah Baumbach for Best Director & Best Screenplay, Adam Driver for Best Actor, & Scarlett Johansson for Best Actress. Marriage Story is a MUST-SEE FILM that is now streaming on Netflix. It will be high on my list of Best Films of 2019.

"All in all, Noah Baumbach delivers what I believe to be its career-best flick, Marriage Story. With the best screenplay of 2019, as well as one the best directions, this is the closest the world is ever going to get to a realistic depiction of a divorce. Technically, both Baumbach and the entire cast are absolutely perfect. It's an extremely emotional narrative, very depressing, sad, and even uncomfortable at times, which might scare some people off, especially if they've been through this.
